description: The Los Angeles rapper’s final album before his 20-year sentence is anxious, forlorn, and self-assured—the violence simmers just below its cool and breezy surface.

title: The Graduation
label: Broyal
description: The debut from the amazing, helium-huffing Atlanta rapper features production from Brodinski and a grip of other European producers that makes it a standout among the city’s rising stars.

title: High as Hope
label: Republic
description: Another relatively stripped-down album featuring the titanic voice of Florence Welch is troubled by its overwhelmingly beige production.

title: I’m All Ears
label: Transgressive
description: The second album from the UK duo is future-pop at its best: kaleidoscopic production and incisive lyrics that swirl into marvelous, breathtaking songs.

title: Topdown Dialectic
label: Peak Oil
description: The anonymous artist’s rustling, swirling ambient techno is as immediate and enveloping as anything leftfield electronic music has produced this year.

title: Sixth House
label: Merge
description: In the 1990s, the Georgia underdogs influenced a generation of indie rockers with their theatrical, reverb-soaked anthems. Nearly two decades later, their first reunion album is more than a throwback.

title: Desolation
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: The Denver doom metal band’s third album is streamlined, expansive, and melodically sharp.

title: Intra
label: Boomkat Editions
description: Mark Fell enlists Portugal’s Drumming Grupo de Percussão to perform captivating computer-generated rhythms on the sixxen, a little-known invention of Iannis Xenakis.

title: All the Things That I Did and All the Things That I Didn’t Do
label: Anti-
description: After years of making somber, traditionalist folk on dueling acoustic guitars, Kenneth Pattengale and Joey Ryan expand their palette on the duo’s most engaging and diverse record to date.

title: Scorpion
label: Young Money Entertainment
description: Drake’s fifth proper studio album is richly produced, studded with gems, and grapples with his fatherhood in a way that casts his arrested development into sharp relief.

title: Incesticide
label: DGC
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the radical underbelly of Nirvana’s 1992 compilation Incesticide.

title: Both Directions at Once: The Lost Album
label: Impulse!
description: The newly discovered, unreleased album from 1963 featuring the “classic quartet” finds the jazz giant thrillingly caught between shoring up and surging forth.

title: Errorzone
label: Closed Casket Activities
description: Yesterday’s Active Rock playlist gets ransacked and reconfigured on the debut full-length from a Boston hardcore quintet whose influences range from Converge to Korn.

title: Hello It’s Me
label: Arrowhawk
description: The comedian, actor, musician, and professional personality recounts a miserable breakup with disarming sincerity and grim humor on a solo debut steeped in rock history.

title: Sink Ya Teeth
label: Hey Buffalo
description: Maria Uzor and Gemma Cullingford channel ESG, Liquid Liquid, and New Order but surpass mere genre mimicry on a debut album that captures the feeling as well as the sounds of classic dance music.

title: The Now Now
label: Parlophone
description: The allure of isolation defines Damon Albarn’s latest project. With only a few guests on the album, he writes simple, mostly upbeat songs with words of exhaustion.

title: Passwords
label: HUB
description: On their sixth album, the Los Angeles rockers attempt to reach across the political spectrum, but their noble intentions clash with cloying lyrics and worn-out arrangements.

title: Zebra
label: Mexican Summer
description: With a large group of collaborators, Alexis Georgopoulos has crafted a pulsing, eclectic, wonderfully breezy album of ethereal psychedelia.

title: Joytime II
label: Marshmello
description: On his second album, the quasi-anonymous DJ in a stylized marshmallow mask proves the perfect figurehead for a commercial EDM scene running on fumes.

title: Freddie
label: ESGN
description: Freddie feels like a pure and reckless purge from Gibbs, a collection that finds him at his wildest and most essential.

title: Renaissance Man
label: Lex
description: The Bronx rapper’s second album in two months has the intimacy of voicemails to a close friend and the warmth of Lil B in his most generous BasedGod form.

title: Year of the Snitch
label: Third Worlds
description: The prolific noise rap project drills down on their sonic signature and remains politically agnostic and persistently agitated.

title: Come to Canada You Will Like It
label: Verdicchio
description: On an album meant to strike “a balance between rural and city living,” the Canadian producer evokes rural idyll in dozy deep house, but the mood too often verges on soporific.

title: Hawaiki Tapes
label: Umor Rex
description: Recorded on the humble Korg Volca FM during a vacation on the Big Island of Hawaii, this atmospheric, unobtrusive album lives somewhere between landscape sketch and spiritual sojourn.

title: Wet Will Always Dry
label: TERNESC
description: The UK techno titan’s debut album is a display of his sound-design prowess—as well as a reminder that even the heaviest techno needn’t shy from the pleasures of weirdo pop.

title: K.T.S.E.
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: Teyana Taylor and her tremendous voice are so deft at performing modernist soul with the genre’s forebears as her backdrop, and her album features some of the best Old Kanye beats heard this year.

title: 200% Galcher
label: Lustwerk Music
description: Five years after his breakthrough mixtape, the former upstart has become a veteran. On his second album in eight months, the rough edges give way to the assured pleasures of an expert in his zone.

title: Lord of Lords
label: Superior Viaduct
description: Alice Coltrane’s newly reissued Lord of Lords capped off a trio of richly orchestral albums in the early ’70s. It is a slow-building, cosmic, unnerving throbbing organism of sound.

title: International Artist
label: Highbridge
description: The latest project from the Bronx rapper enlists musicians from across the globe for an attempted cross-cultural exchange of Afrobeat, dancehall, and reggaeton to mixed effect.

title: Simple Answers
label: Last Things
description: The Psalm Zero frontman and Zs alum reckons with the rise of fascism—and his internal struggle against its insidious appeal—on a debut solo album of unusually confrontational modern classical music.

title: Heaven’s Only Wishful EP
label: Don’t Guess
description: Toronto musician Seth Nyquist’s versatile voice soars on every track of an inviting debut that spans a surprising array of genres and techniques.

title: Dies Iræ Xerox
label: Dial
description: The Rhode Island native’s second album of noisy, downbeat techno is a cocoon ringed with razor wire—the kind of music that’s perfect for headphones and subway journeys when you’re in a foul mood.

title: Kazuashita
label: 4AD
description: On their first album in seven years, the New York fusionists tap into a welter of global styles; the result is soft-edged and idyllic, yet hides a subtle political undercurrent.

title: для FOR
label: Rvng Intl.
description: The Russian electronic musician Kate NV’s sonic portrait of her native Moscow is surreal, otherworldly, and playfully inscrutable.

title: To Record Only Water for Ten Days
label: Warner Bros.
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the haunting and beautiful 2001 solo album from the Red Hot Chili Peppers’ John Frusciante.

title: Redemption
label: Top Dawg
description: After a life-threatening motorcycle accident, Jay Rock returns with his strongest album yet, a collection of rap songs that highlight his struggle and journey.

title: Bad Witch
label: The Null Corporation
description: Trent Reznor’s third EP-length NIN release in the last two years is the best of the lot, with a raw and rough sound that feels both unfinished and alive.

title: Post Traumatic
label: Warner Bros.
description: On his debut solo album, the Linkin Park rapper and producer mourns the death of his bandmate Chester Bennington but never translates that grief into candid lyrics or inspired songwriting.

title: Babelsberg
label: Rough Trade
description: The Super Furry Animals frontman has always been political, but he’s never sounded as spiteful as he does on this satirical portrait of the United States in 2018.

title: Heaven and Earth
label: Young Turks
description: The latest from the saxophonist and bandleader is a multi-genre feast of musical ideas, his most sweeping and complete statement yet.

label: Cash Money
description: The 24-year-old Cash Money singer upcycles ’90s R&B hits on an album of charmingly naughty sex jams—but his referential style is more than just a schtick.

title: June
label: Thrill Jockey
description: In the 37-minute piece that comprises his first solo album since 2005, the Mountains multi-instrumentalist ditches the distractions of the attention economy to luxuriate in a stream of consciousness.

title: Lower East Suite Part Three
label: Big Dada
description: The finale of the New York jazz ensemble’s Lower East Suite trilogy marks a shift in tone and finds the band newly focused.

title: Moodie EP
label: Sub Pop
description: The multi-talented Floridian musician flaunts his 2000s indie and emo influences on a debut EP of perky pop that chronicles a post-breakup transformation.

title: Déjàvu
label: Matty Unlimited
description: A breakdown that led BADBADNOTGOOD keyboardist Matty Tavares to move in with his parents also resulted in this breezy, psychedelic soft-rock album recorded with sought-after sample maker Frank Dukes.

title: Nasty
label: Sugar Trap
description: The ferocious 21-year-old shapeshifter comes through with one of the hardest rap records of the year.

title: Call the Comet
label: New Voodoo
description: The former Smiths guitarist absorbs the political shocks of 2016 on a characteristically polished album that imagines life in an alternate universe that values kindness, curiosity, and intelligence.

title: Sorpresa Familia
label: Captured Tracks
description: Label woes finally resolved, the Catalonian quartet gets its frustrations off its chest on its third album, showcasing a newfound maturity of songcraft without sacrificing youthful energy.

title: Nothing Is Still
label: Ninja Tune
description: After two albums of jazzy, humid club cuts, the British producer moves beyond the dancefloor with a stunning concept record about his grandparents that incorporates ambient and modern classical music.

title: Bon Voyage
label: Fat Possum
description: Six years and one nearly fatal accident after her promising debut, French singer-songwriter Melody Prochet celebrates her recovery with an album of gleefully overstuffed psych-pop.

title: Nasir
label: Mass Appeal
description: No longer able to summon his mythical sense of storytelling, Nas sounds lost on his 11th studio album. Kanye’s production doesn’t help, either.

title: Liberation
label: RCA
description: The pop survivor shows off her powerhouse voice, dabbles in try-hard slang, and takes tentative steps toward creative rebirth on her first album since 2012.

title: Ecstatic Arrow
label: Fire
description: On their third album of avant-garde synth pop, Alice Merida Richards and Sam Pillay eschew protest language and the depressing status quo to conjure a vision of feminist utopia.

title: Cloud Corner
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On her Thrill Jockey debut, the solo guitarist creates truly borderless music, fusing the diverse global traditions she favors without drawing too much attention to the act of juxtaposition.

title: Collagically Speaking
label: Blue Note
description: Jazz pianist Robert Glasper assembles an all-star cast in search of a sound that might reflect the tenor of the times; the meditative results are shaded by politics without wallowing in it.

title: Home Boy, Sister Out
label: Wewantsounds
description: This long-forgotten 1985 album is far from the legendary jazz trumpeter’s best work, but look past its awkwardness and dated sonics, and a certain charm reveals itself.

title: Make My Bed EP
label: Zelig Records
description: On a debut EP that occupies a space between the cathartic stadium pop of fun. and the vulnerability of Lorde, the young singer-producer offers the kind of love songs generations of queer kids craved.

title: Head Over Heels
label: Big Beat
description: On their bona fide all-stars album, everyone from DRAM to Amber Mark to The-Dream cannot save the electronic duo from their tastelessness.

title: New Bodies
label: Temporary Residence
description: The Australian instrumentalists have always used their breathtaking technical dexterity to craft songs that feel like little worlds. Their fourth album fills those spaces with emotion.

title: Stranger Fruit
label: MVKA Music
description: Manuel Gagneux’s latest provocative mix of black metal and Southern folk and gospel music is an absurd union that provides moments of vitality and stark political statements about race in America.

title: Come Tomorrow
label: RCA
description: The long-running jam band’s ninth album centers on hard-earned optimism but smooths out much of what makes Dave Matthews’ music engaging.

title: Hereditary (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Milan
description: The saxophonist’s soundtrack to the unsettling horror movie feeds off his darkest impulses as a composer, amplifying and mirroring the trauma and fear on the screen.

title: Consolation EP
label: Domino
description: The four-song EP from the Michigan post-punk band features Kelley Deal of the Breeders and some of the most pointed and impactful songwriting of their career.

title: Devotion
label: Chapter
description: The Australian folk-turned-pop singer revisits her eccentric, romantically unfulfilled teen years on an album that reaches for the coming-of-age immediacy of artists like Lorde and Taylor Swift.

title: OIL OF EVERY PEARL’s UN-INSIDES
label: Transgressive
description: The experimental music of SOPHIE relaxes into new forms on her debut album. It is sprawling and beautiful, while still keeping the disorienting, latex-pop feel of her fascinating production technique.

title: Hope Downs
label: Sub Pop
description: The “120 Minutes” revivalists trade manic exuberance for panicked agitation on a debut album that applies their infectious brand of motorik jangle rock to lovelorn ruminations and geopolitical laments.

title: Showtime EP
label: XL
description: On his first release for the iconic British label XL, the Swedish deep house trickster leans into his pop proclivities and heavy-lidded Lothario persona.

title: Mental Wounds Not Healing
label: Sacred Bones
description: Extreme-metal titans and prolific collaborators the Body team with New York-based industrial duo Uniform on a brutally satisfying—and surprisingly melodic—joint album.

title: Remain in Light
label: Kravenworks
description: Inspired by its Afrobeat underpinnings, the Beninese singer tackles an album-length cover of the Talking Heads’ 1980 landmark, in the process unearthing hidden rhythmic and emotional nuances.

title: soil
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Taking full advantage of his voluminous, one-of-a-kind voice, experimental pop artist serpentwithfeet offers complex visions of queer love on his debut album.

title: IRISIRI
label: Pan
description: On her third album, the Queens experimental musician explores the way women’s voices can challenge the norms of taste and decorum and push past the boundaries of accepted musical language.

title: Bruce Wayne
label: 300 Entertainment
description: The 28-minute EP continues Fetty Wap’s steady decline from promising trap balladeer to one-dimensional chant rapper.

title: No Shame
label: Warner Bros.
description: Pilloried in the press for her every misfortune, Lily Allen scrutinizes her public persona on an album that dilutes staggering sincerity with uninspired beats.

title: so sad so sexy
label: RCA
description: With festival-ready hooks and trap-inspired production, Lykke Li delivers another record about an unraveling romance and the fraught sexuality of its final moments with diminishing returns.

title: Lost & Found
label: FAMM
description: The precocious 20-year-old singer fuses R&B, soul, and trip-hop on a debut album that documents her ongoing quest to discover who she is and how she fits into a troubled world.

title: Constant Image
label: Domino
description: As D.C. punks with ties to Priests, Fugazi, and Comet Ping Pong, Flasher are expected to have something to say about politics in 2018—but their debut album would have felt just as timely 30 years ago.

title: Whack World
label: self-released
description: The surreal, audiovisual album from the Philadelphia artist is only 15 minutes long, but it is overflowing with hooks and a powerful sense of imagination.

title: Insula
label: Hyperdub
description: Still a child during grime’s original heyday, the Edinburgh producer approaches the genre with a collagist’s appreciation for layering, juxtaposition, and hyper-referentiality.

title: Childqueen
label: Fat Possum
description: The psych-soul singer summons the confidence and exuberance of childhood on an immersive sophomore album.

title: Shannon in Nashville
label: Easy Eye Sound
description: The gale-force frontwoman of Shannon and the Clams collaborates with producer Dan Auerbach on a sparkling debut solo album that sounds like Roy Orbison lost in the Brill Building.

title: The Band
label: Capitol
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the collectivism of the Band’s 1969 self-titled album.

title: An ASMR Album
label: Nice Life
description: The extremely online 25-year-old comedian’s foray into a more traditional comedy format makes for an imposing and uneven listen, even for the most logged-on.

title: 3rd Ward Bounce EP
label: Asylum
description: The bounce queen’s latest EP marks her return to the unctuous, mechanized mother tongue of New Orleans.

title: Kicker EP
label: Polyvinyl
description: After nearly 20 years of playing against their strengths, the Get Up Kids jump on the “adult emo” bandwagon and recapture the punk immediacy of their late-’90s heyday.

title: Lightlessness Is Nothing New
label: Barsuk
description: After a six-year hiatus, the Chicago math-rock-turned-pop-rock act returns with a deceptively upbeat album inspired by the death of singer-guitarist Dave Davison’s father.

title: Listening to Pictures (Pentimento Volume One)
label: Ndeya
description: On his first album in nine years, the Los Angeles trumpeter-composer sounds like he’s remixing himself, taking apart his past 40 years of work and reassembling it for the present moment.

title: Our Raw Heart
label: Relapse
description: The long-running Oregon doom metal trio opens its third act with a sensuous, aggressive, and jubilant album inspired by singer-guitarist Mike Scheidt's recent brush with death.

title: Lush
label: Matador
description: Snail Mail’s striking debut album is emotionally wise, musically clear, and encompasses the once and future sound of indie rock.

title: Both
label: Heavy Body
description: King Krule collaborator Kaya Wilkins escapes music-industry servitude and speaks truth on her own terms in a frank, often melancholy bedroom-pop debut leavened by diaristic sarcasm.

title: LUMP
label: Dead Oceans
description: On their first collaborative album, Laura Marling and Tunng’s Mike Lindsay wrap prickly observations about lifestyle consumerism in bales of gorgeous melody and grumbling dissonance.

title: Stereo EP
label: self-released
description: The Indiana singer-songwriter brings his seductive falsetto and clever production touches to a short, sweet debut EP of bedroom pop and throwback soul.

title: Strata EP
label: Once In A Blue Moon
description: Named after an architectural icon looming over South East London, the rapper’s six-track EP offers a detailed account of life at the building’s base.

title: Prequelle
label: Loma Vista
description: Unmasked in 2017 as Ghost’s mastermind, Tobias Forge trades in his papal regalia for a new persona on a darkly comic album that is lots of fun despite its flaws.

title: The Future and the Past
label: ATO
description: The singer-songwriter follows up her gloriously baroque debut with an album that uses deep grooves, politicized self-portraiture, and an eye for everyday cruelty to reckon with life in the Trump era.

title: Still EP
label: Rhymes of an Hour
description: The dream-pop legends breathe new life into old songs on a slight, unsurprising, but reliably lovely EP of dreamy desert blues.

title: Streams of Thought, Vol. 1
label: Human Re Sources
description: After 30 years fronting the Roots, Black Thought has finally put out his first solo EP. It is rigorous but rarely hermetic, a small testament to his sustained excellence.

title: You, Forever
label: Saddle Creek
description: Celestial Shore singer-guitarist Sam Owens puts his own actions and desires under a microscope on a gentle, sunny, yet boldly honest solo album.

title: Patina Echoes
label: Timedance
description: Released by UK bass scion Batu, this survey of cutting-edge club music is less a collection of voices than a shared statement of purpose, full of thrilling rhythms and textures.

title: Winning Star Champion
label: Barsuk
description: Seattle indie scene veteran Matt Batey contrasts bouncy power-pop with lyrics about anxiety and failure on his cathartic solo debut for Barsuk.

title: Sacrifices
label: Lex
description: Returning to his best-known alias, the veteran hip-hop deconstructionist scales back his approach, but Sacrifices can feel slight, with songs that too often fade into the background.

title: Assimilation
label: Where to Now?
description: Fresh off a thrilling collaboration with Joy Orbison, the British saxophonist teams with Mica Levi, Rupert Clervaux, and others on an audacious solo album that feels like another team effort.

title: Hell-On
label: Anti-
description: On her self-produced seventh solo LP, Neko Case brings on a bunch of collaborators for a dense album that searches for connection amid human cruelty and chaos.

title: ye
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: Kanye West’s stint in Wyoming created an album born from chaos for chaos’ sake. Though it can be somewhat fascinating, it is undoubtedly a low point in his career.

title: The Long Sleep
label: Sacred Bones
description: The experimental songwriter abandons the conceptual rigor of her recent albums, collaborating with a handful of jazz musicians on a loose, ambiguous EP where repetition induces a state of déjà vu.

title: Wildness
label: Polydor
description: On his band's first album in seven years, Gary Lightbody aims for clarity, connection, and personal resonance but lapses into the pomp and incoherence that have plagued Snow Patrol for a decade.

title: Deeper
label: Fire Talk
description: The Chicago quartet’s debut is well-oiled and worn-in indie rock, played with the precision and confidence typically expected from a band much further along in its career.

title: Live Through This
label: City Slang
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the righteous anger of Hole’s 1994 album Live Through This.

title: Return of the Frog Queen
label: Sub Pop
description: The Sunny Day Real Estate leader's 1996 solo debut is often viewed through the prism of his Christian rebirth. Sub Pop's reissue reveals how its orchestral grandeur helped shape indie rock's future.

title: Age Of
label: Warp
description: The tenth album from Daniel Lopatin is his most collaborative and accessible solo project to date, yet still full of unexpected chaos and songs that can suddenly dissolve and disarm.

title: Lush Life
label: Mysteries of Trade
description: The Toronto duo follows up an eight-year-old debut EP with an album that gestures toward various eras of dancehall and traverses a range of emotion.

title: Dream House
label: Innervisions
description: The Berlin tech-house duo’s debut album purports to expand its palette, but an impressive list of collaborators can’t keep the music from lapsing into middle-of-the-road anonymity.

title: Skulls Example
label: Orindal
description: Katy Davidson’s indie-folk project returns on an album that mines philosophical poetry from moments when ancient natural wonders meet modern technology.

title: Cruel Practice
label: NUXXE
description: On her debut EP, South East London singer and DJ Blane Muise combines venomous lyricism with tar-boiling industrial beats to inhabit a fierce, sexual, pathologically impatient, and deeply cathartic alter ego.

title: Goodbye & Good Riddance
label: Grade A
description: Juice WRLD’s emo-rap debut is an adolescent breakup record that is equal parts endearing and grating.

title: God’s Favorite Customer
label: Sub Pop
description: Josh Tillman is still self-absorbed. But his fourth full-length as Father John Misty exhibits a new sense of empathy and vulnerability while losing none of his wit.

title: Cave Vaults of the Moon
label: Séance Centre
description: The Taos composer’s 1987 accompaniment to a sculpture exhibition with a sci-fi bent makes for a synth-heavy adventure in new age that’s by turns eerie and playful.

title: V.
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The dyed-in-the-wool psych-rock band returns with some of their most accessible songs to date, full of fuzz-pedal jams that capture moments of fleeting happiness in dark days.

title: Diary 001 EP
label: Fader
description: The lo-fi pop singer’s first label release is an EP whose careful songwriting and intriguingly flat vocals should quiet naysayers who dismissed her as a one-hit fluke.

title: Vibras
label: Universal Music Latino
description: The reggaetonero’s latest sets him up for even more global success. Its infectious vibe is draped in dancehall with a dash of trap production and nods to salsa, bachata, and Afrobeat.

title: Shawn Mendes
label: Island
description: On his third album, the former Vine star grows into a persona that’s playful, gently libidinous, and safely menace-free, but his music too often falls on the wrong side of beige.

title: Love Is Dead
label: Glassnote
description: With help from some outside producers, Chvrches’ try to launch themselves into the mainstream. The result is an uncomplicated, unsurprising collection of steely synth pop.

title: cc EP
label: self-released
description: After last year’s Tommy EP, the South London electronic musician turns her abstracted sound collages to more pointedly cathartic ends: complex music that brims with conflicting emotions.

title: Medicaid Fraud Dogg
label: C Kunspyruhzy
description: On their first album in 38 years, George Clinton and his impressive band channel the Parliament of old for something decidedly modern. It’s delightfully raunchy but also surprisingly tenderhearted.

title: Tracyanne & Danny
label: Merge
description: Five years after Camera Obscura’s last album, Tracyanne Campbell returns with a new musical partner and a more mannered, slightly cautious sound, but her voice is as singular as ever.

title: Sink EP
label: Stones Throw
description: The genre-defying violinist levels up as a songwriter on an EP of experimental pop and R&B. It explodes conventional musical logic with disarming ease.

title: Paz & Amor EP
label: Príncipe Discos
description: The Lisbon producer’s solo debut takes the spiky, polyrhythmic sound of Portuguese batida and bends it toward a sleek dancefloor sensibility, making for Príncipe’s most accessible release yet.

title: Midnight Marker
label: Beats in Space
description: On Shy Layers’ second album, his chill-but-adventurous aesthetic snaps into clearer focus. Highlife, funk, Ethio-jazz, and more all swirl together in every measure of music.

title: Testing
label: RCA
description: On his third studio album, Rocky is more experimental and personal. But for music that relies on the New York rapper’s artful intuitions, it’s unfortunate his intuitions are often very basic.

title: Black Soap
label: Lex
description: The 19-year-old rapper’s latest project is a quest of self-discovery that serves as a reminder of the power and dexterity New York’s new vanguard of artists.

title: Only Built 4 Cuban Linx
label: Loud
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Raekwon’s game-changing 1995 debut Only Built 4 Cuban Linx.

title: Big Wave More Fire
label: Loma Vista
description: The LA-based electronic duo that gave Kanye’s The Life of Pablo its gospel-house sheen embraces pop on an album featuring guest vocals by Amber Mark, Khalid, and The-Dream.

title: Sugar & Spice EP
label: Double Double Whammy
description: On her well-formed debut EP, Harriette Pilbeam's version of dream pop is more pop than dream.

title: Themes for Television
label: Italians Do It Better
description: The surprise release collects unheard material originally meant for “Twin Peaks: The Return”; though slighter than this year’s Digital Rain EP, it might be Jewel’s strongest soundtrack work yet.

title: The Return
label: Black Focus
description: Following the dissolution of the jazz-funk duo Yussef Kamaal, the London keyboardist returns with an urbane, dynamic album that’s deeply rooted in the city’s rhythms.

title: (((echo chamber)))
label: Mello Music Group
description: On his first album in nearly a decade, the absurdist rapper uses his enormous vocabulary to riff on race, class, and becoming a parent—but he still hasn’t outgrown of fart jokes.

title: Daytona
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: Produced entirely by Kanye West, the spare and serrated solo album from Pusha-T is a near-airtight exercise in flair and focus.

title: Perfume EP
label: Drag City
description: Cory Hanson and his SoCal cohorts continue their transformation from manic garage rockers to shape-shifting innovators on an EP as eclectic as White Light/White Heat.

title: Light of Mine
label: Atlantic
description: The carefree California rapper’s debut is an exceedingly joyous and self-aware slice of pop rap.

title: Love Yourself 轉 ‘Tear’
label: BigHit Entertainment
description: The latest album from the masters of the K-pop formula is a slick, loosely thematic album about love and loss, with a stronger emphasis on rapping than ever before.

title: Reckless
label: XO
description: The Toronto rapper’s debut is a long shot at cementing his legacy that is plagued by indecision and self-doubt.

title: Harder Than Ever
label: Quality Control
description: Lil Baby’s official debut is technically impressive: polished, efficient, but also kind of nondescript.

title: Deeper Woods
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On her third solo album, North Carolina guitarist Sarah Louise Henson steps beyond her vivid acoustic work and into a realm of glowing studio experimentation and layered vocals.

title: Luminosity Device
label: Dynamic Tension
description: Inspired by the Tibetan Book of the Dead, the Birmingham techno producer puts a fresh spin on his pummeling club tracks; the album is equally suited for dancefloor abandon and spiritual searching.

title: Angels of Death
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: The Toronto singer’s album is a country and gospel-infused meditation on death and mourning that flickers between the broadly universal and the devastatingly personal.

title: Tell Me How You Really Feel
label: Mom & Pop
description: Courtney Barnett’s second album is smaller, more introverted than her debut. It’s tentative but with a purpose, songs about what it means to not have—or need—the right words for everything.

title: Yesterday’s Tomorrows
label: Wolf
description: On his third album, Berlin producer Sebastian Genz switches up his dreamy house sound with forays into drum ‘n’ bass and boom-bap hip-hop but can’t shake his nostalgia addiction.

title: Deafman Glance
label: Dead Oceans
description: After several albums of traditional, jazzy folk-rock, the Chicago-based singer-songwriter finds a more instinctive voice.

title: Wax Chattels
label: Captured Tracks
description: Billing itself as a “guitarless guitar band,” the New Zealand noise-rock trio endeavors to make bass, keyboard, and two-piece drum kit sound as loud as possible.

title: Happy Ending
label: Etruscan Gold
description: Wax Idols complete their transformation from sardonic post-punks to theatrical goth-rock storytellers on an album that dares to take pleasure in confronting death.

title: Saved
label: Trans
description: Now, Now trade guitar rock and raw nerves for slick, left-of-center pop on a deceptively upbeat comeback album whose intense lyrics and unsettling sounds stay true to the duo’s emo roots.

title: Wide Awake!
label: Rough Trade
description: On their fourth album, Parquet Courts enlist Danger Mouse to produce an album of joyfully absurd, danceable rock music. It is straightforward but alien, simple but endlessly referential.

title: Spirit in the Dark
label: Atlantic
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Aretha Franklin’s immensely personal 1970 album Spirit in the Dark.

title: Buck Meek
label: Keeled Scales
description: The debut solo album from the Big Thief guitarist has a quiet and mischevious spirit, with a focus put on his nimble playing and Texas twang.

title: Cannonball!
label: 88rising
description: The Kyoto-born, Chicago-based multi-instrumentalist uses his nonchalant flow and the sharp instincts he acquired playing saxophone as a kid to craft a dynamic, introspective jazz-rap debut.

title: Hundreds of Days
label: Ghostly International
description: The harp innovator experiments with an arsenal of new instruments—including her voice—on an album of ambient music as complex and meditative as the work of Pauline Oliveros.

title: Violet Psalms
label: Paper Bag
description: On what the band has said is its final album, Frog Eyes sound galvanized by the prospect of bowing out, resulting in their strongest record in years.

title: Rausch
label: Kompakt
description: Wolfgang Voigt’s investigations of German heritage turn ominous on an imposing, hour-long ambient album whose title translates as “frenzy”; it feels closely keyed to the current political state.

title: Letters of Irrelevance
label: EMPIRE
description: Following his bandmates Syd, Matt Martians, and Steve Lacy, the bassist of L.A.’s the internet steps up with his solo debut. He’s not yet a natural leader, but his musicianship is self-evident.

title: Sparkle Hard
label: Matador
description: On his fetching seventh solo album, the witty and digressive songwriting of Stephen Malkmus becomes newly and delightfully grounded in the present day.

title: Period
label: Quality Control
description: Rappers JT and Yung Miami give the menstrual cycle top billing on a debut that showcases their synergy but doesn’t deliver the transgressive goods its title promises.

title: To Drink From the Night Itself
label: Century Media
description: The Swedish melodic death metal innovators crib from a career highlight, 1994’s Terminal Spirit Disease, on their first reunion album that does justice to their legacy.

title: Faminine Mystique
label: Nihjgt Feelings
description: The witch-house pioneer and a Berlin-based producer join forces on a purposefully “difficult-to-digest” album whose sprawling array of references and styles mimics life online.

title: Compro
label: Ilian Tape
description: The German producer Brian Müller has a preternatural feel for the dancefloor, and his latest is a shining hybrid of breakbeats and ambient textures, making it one of the best dance records of the year.

title: Die Lit
label: AWGE
description: The Atlanta rapper’s official debut is an album that works almost completely from its own lunatic script. It is a perversely infectious sugar high, rap that fundamentally recalibrates the brain’s reward centers.

title: Failed Celestial Creatures
label: Empty Editions
description: The Gastr del Sol founder melds minds with a Japanese guitarist and electronic musician who shares his skewed approach to songwriting on an album inspired by the work of novelist Atsushi Nakajima.

title: In the Rainbow Rain
label: ATO
description: Will Sheff makes kindness an aesthetic on this album of gentle, idiosyncratic songs about dog adoption, celebrities’ emergency tracheotomies and finding transcendence in nature.

title: Mark Kozelek
label: Caldo Verde
description: The songwriter’s latest great long ode to himself is at once bloated and transcendent, boring and mesmerizing.

title: Kiss Yr Frenemies
label: Tiny Engines
description: Veteran studio rat Sarah Tudzin steps out from behind the boards on a debut album that uses the timeless conventions of indie-pop to capture the experience of being a young adult in 2018.

title: NORF: The Legend of Hotboy Ronald
label: NewAgeNarcissism
description: On his debut album, the Milwaukee rapper Lorde Fredd33 emerges fully-formed. He is charismatic and nuanced, painting a complex, deeply-personal portrait of black life in America’s rust belt.

title: O
label: Dero Arcade
description: Cody Critcheloe’s witty multimedia alt-pop project exults in uncensored queerness on an album that fulfills the musician and filmmaker’s maximalist ambitions.

title: Tranquility Base Hotel & Casino
label: Domino
description: Arctic Monkeys’ daring sixth album is a left-turn if ever there was one, but the way Alex Turner swaps witty sleaze for absurdist suave makes it a totally bemusing and fascinating listen.

title: On Watch
label: LandLand
description: The debut from the Chicago post-hardcore group revels in playing with teeth-gritting tension and dynamics, defining their sound by its restraint as much as its rage.

title: Activated
label: 300 Entertainment
description: The Detroit rapper’s debut album aims for a mix of transparency and commercial ambition, but he struggles to hold his own amid so much high-stakes production.

title: Time Out of Mind
label: Columbia
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Bob Dylan’s masterful comeback, 1997’s Time Out of Mind.

title: Marely Barch
label: Halloween
description: Recorded at home on his mother’s laptop, Barely March’s debut album is a scrappy, tuneful album of post-breakup self-deprecation that recognizes the absurdity of wallowing in your own bullshit.

title: Beware the Book of Eli
label: Victor Victor
description: The South Florida rapper sounds like a hip-hop Hades on a menacing, underworldly mixtape leavened by cracked psychedelia, surreal humor, and straight-up weirdness.

title: Baylor Swift
label: TWIN
description: As its title suggests, the Atlanta rapper’s album is pop-focused and geared for emo. She sounds reborn, retrofitting her scrappy rap with Technicolor pop-punk for songs about overcoming heartbreak.

title: Any Day
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On their first album in six years, the post-rock stalwarts bring new urgency to their signature gliding rhythms, jazz-inflected guitar lines, and analog synth tones.

title: Fall in Love EP
label: Hush Hush
description: On his second solo EP, the Seattle producer weaves together samples, field recordings, and original instrumentation to craft tactile electronic music that’s beat-oriented yet meditative.

label: Sub Pop
description: Beach House remain masters of the indefinable and their seventh album is their heaviest and most immersive-sounding of their career.

title: Murmurations
label: Wichita
description: Simian Mobile Disco team up with all-female singing collective Deep Throat Choir for an adventurous full-length that is their first album to prominently feature vocals in nearly a decade.

title: JP3
label: self-released
description: On her third album, the New York rapper sounds as joyfully lascivious as ever, but slower and funkier, casting aside trifling men and centering her own self-fulfillment.

title: DNA Feelings
label: Houndstooth
description: The Swiss producer reframes electronic music as a mode of spiritual searching on an album that deemphasizes grooves and lyrics in favor of icy, alien sounds and high, inscrutable cries.

title: Singularity
label: Domino
description: Pitched between heat-seeking acid house and ambient bliss, the techno auteur’s first album since 2013 is a beat-music odyssey that thrums with spiritual resonance.

title: Simi
label: Bloc Nation
description: On the heels of a viral dance and a Drake feature, the Memphis rapper’s latest mixtape is a breakthrough that’s honest, clear, and incredibly fun.

title: Downtown Castles Can Never Block the Sun
label: International Anthem
description: On his debut album, the uncategorizable Chicago musician knits together experimental jazz, funk playfulness, Brazilian rhythms, and the sensuality of Prince.

title: The Horizon Just Laughed
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Two decades into his career, these songs are among the most incisive but somehow most complex ones Jurado has ever written, lined up from end to end without a wasted note, layer, line, or word.

title: Conexão EP
label: PMR
description: The New York singer’s casually elegant EP is remarkably accomplished. Even at just four songs, Amber Mark sounds like a veteran of pop songcraft and performance.

title: L.O.D. EP
label: Def Jam
description: The 21-year-old Kanye West acolyte and Future soundalike tries again to step out of his elders’ shadows on an EP that is unlikely to quiet his critics.

title: Until Death Call My Name
label: Never Broke Again, LLC
description: The 18-year-old Baton Rouge rapper’s debut album is packed with allegories on power that illuminate but don’t apologize for his well-publicized history of violence.

title: Appreciation
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: On Horse Feathers’ sixth album, their introverted persona has thawed, revealing a surprising affinity for the joy of Stax-era and country-fried soul.

title: DOVE
label: Belly Touring
description: On their first album in over 20 years, Tanya Donelly and her band conjure the same potent mix of grace and force that fueled their 1990s output.

title: SR3MM
label: Eardruma
description: The triple album from Slim Jxmmi and Swae Lee is their clearest personal statement yet, a shining triptych of what it looks like to be young, black, and euphoric.

title: Good Thing
label: LisaSawyer63
description: The second, more adventurous album from the Texas soul singer bends toward the present while keeping the warmth of classic R&B in his melodies and songwriting.

title: Music for Installations
label: UMC
description: Though containing music that goes back to 1985, Music For Installations is hardly a retrospective in any traditional sense. It’s more a whimsical line connecting ideas in Eno's own personal Long Now.

title: Starting Today
label: Brownswood
description: This solo debut from a fixture of London’s vital and eclectic jazz community delves into dub, soul, and fusion on a journey from the scene’s diverse roots to its exhilarating present.

title: Beyondless
label: Matador
description: On their astonishing fourth album, the Danish punk band reach for pop-gothic grandeur with more tenacity and abandon than ever.

title: Rejuvenate
label: R&S
description: Danny Brown’s go-to producer abandons his sampledelic style for an album of original beats and inspired guest vocals that reveal who he really is as a solo artist.

title: The Flowers of Romance
label: Virgin
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we offer a first-hand account of the brilliant chaos of PiL’s The Flowers of Romance.

title: Blue Dream EP
label: self-released
description: Dropping the club-centric vibe of his previous work, the New York rapper shifts toward trap and Top 40 rap sounds—an unconventional move that might be more progressive than it seems.

title: Venetian Snares x Daniel Lanois
label: Timesig
description: The ambient guitarist and the breakcore wizard bring diametrically opposed instincts and skill sets to an album that strikes an uneasy balance between calm and chaos.

title: The Good Is a Big God
label: Luaka Bop
description: Working alongside his longtime bandmates Moreno Veloso and Alexandre Kassin, plus the string arranger Sean O’Hagan, the Rio multi-instrumentalist ponders Brazilian music’s rootedness.

title: Lost Friends
label: Domino
description: The Australian trio’s debut album deals in radiant, anthemic indie rock, balancing doubt-ridden lyrics with clear-eyed execution.

title: Chiquito EP
label: self-released
description: The short EP from the California singer showcases his ear for cool sounds, and every track puts his dynamic personality and oddly calibrated synths front and center.

title: Hello People
label: Flemish Eye
description: This lovingly curated posthumous album collects a decade’s worth of unreleased ambient compositions by the late Women guitarist.

title: Anticlines
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Lucrecia Dalt’s sixth album is a marvelous exploration of mercurial ambient music whose aesthetic is so singular, it feels like she dreamed it into being.

title: Rebound
label: Frenchkiss
description: On her fourth solo album, Eleanor Friedberger embraces ’80s goth pop and explores a newly fragmented internal landscape as a post-election expat in Greece.

title: Knock Knock
label: Pampa
description: Listening to Stefan Kozalla’s latest is an essential experience. He finds the moments that express wistful longing, burrows into them, and then blows it all up to color-saturated widescreen.

title: House With a Pool
label: Ghost Ramp
description: The Houston rapper Fat Tony teams with Los Angeles producer Kyle Mabson for a noisy, synth-funk, outré record that often gels together and pushes at the boundaries of experimental rap.

title: Hollow Ground
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Max Clarke balances vintage recording methods with expressive songwriting on the ’60s-style pop ballads that fill his debut album as Cut Worms.

title: Beerbongs & Bentleys
label: Republic
description: The second album from the crossover star features a few inarguable pop hits, but Post Malone’s singular, dour mood wears thin and grows stale after too long.

title: Poo Bear Presents: Bearthday Music
label: Capitol
description: The songwriter extraordinaire lets guests and producers steal his spotlight, making for a pop compilation that is interchangeably chill, spanning every genre at its absolute lowest key.

title: Sway
label: Sony
description: Fascinated by the psychology behind human connection, the Swedish pop singer celebrates all varieties of romantic vulnerability on her exuberant third album.

title: Girly-Sound to Guyville: The 25th Anniversary Box Set
label: Matador
description: Liz Phair’s indelible, essential debut album has been reissued with three crucial bedroom tapes that further define the innovative and unselfconscious songwriting from early in her career.

title: With Dim Light
label: Guruguru Brain
description: Krautrock, psychedelia, and a DJ’s flair for track sequencing come together on an album that proves this Tokyo trio is more than just a revival act.

title: Only Love
label: Throat Ruiner
description: The second album from the Detroit hardcore collective is as ambitious as it is effective. Noise, art rock, and a surprising amount of hooks are knotted within their chaotic maximalism.

title: Dirty Computer
label: Atlantic
description: Ever the innovator, Janelle Monáe has crafted a singular, youthful pop record that is the culmination of years of silence and deflection in order to one day be free.

title: Facepaint EP
label: Future Classic
description: Sasha Spielberg reunites with her Just Friends bandmate, Nicolas Jaar, for a somber solo EP that finds the Wardell singer forging an identity of her own.

title: You’re Driving Me Crazy
label: Legacy
description: On his third album in seven months, Morrison teams up with jazz musician Joey DeFrancesco for a collection of originals and standards that captures the joy of making music.

title: Elysia Crampton
label: Break World
description: On her fourth album, Elysia Crampton continues staking out an anti-colonialist conception of time. It blooms from big, propulsive drum patterns while conjuring a sense of profound loneliness.

title: Grid of Points
label: Kranky
description: Liz Harris’ sparse, 22-minute record follows the trajectory of her 2014 album Ruins to a place that feels even more wind-blown and remote.

title: Question and Answer EP
label: The Bunker
description: This brief EP shows just how much ingenuity and fresh new wrinkles Wata Igarashi can wring out of his Roland-909, Ableton, and modular synth set-up.

title: Perfect From Now On
label: Warner Bros.
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Built to Spill’s winding, monumental 1997 album Perfect From Now On.

title: Gate 13
label: Gate13
description: Protean future-funk production steals the show on this collaboration between two veterans of the Bay Area hip-hop scene.

title: Bloodline
label: Apron
description: The London producer pays tribute to his musical and familial heritage on a sophomore album that makes vintage Roland gear sound new again.

title: Crop Circle
label: XL
description: The latest album from the star of UK road rap is an entirely new and impressively unconfined sound with Nines still grounding himself firmly in his past.

title: Spaghetti Factory
label: EMPIRE
description: On his latest mixtape, the Atlanta rapper uses his innate charisma and exacting eye for the details of the drug trade to court a national audience that has so far eluded him.

title: Conquistador
label: Sargent House
description: The drone-metal titan’s “imaginary Western” fleshes out his talents as a storyteller, but this album of mostly solo electric guitar doesn’t feel as fully realized as his band Earth’s best work.

title: Forth Wanderers
label: Sub Pop
description: The Sub Pop debut from the New Jersey indie rock band arrives refreshingly well-formed. Their music has an urbane sensibility, one that feels not just older in age, but in sound.

title: Twerp Verse
label: Carpark
description: Speedy Ortiz’s third album is wry, acerbic, and full of hidden hooks. The songwriting of singer-guitarist Sadie Dupuis has hit a new peak of clarity.

title: Sparrow
label: Warner Music Nashville
description: The Nashville singer-songwriter looks backwards to move forward on an album that filters contemporary desires and sorrows through the timeless vernacular of country.

title: The Sciences
label: Third Man
description: The iconic stoner metal band’s first studio album in almost two decades is a twin ode to volume and weed. It makes everything that was originally great about Sleep even better.

title: Not for Sale
label: Babygrande
description: Harlem rapper Smoke DZA keeps it real on Not For Sale, doubling down on classic hip-hop as he’s got an allergy to trends. That’s mostly a good thing.

label: Interscope
description: The reggae-lite collaboration between Sting and Shaggy is as professional, good-natured, and helplessly uncool as its billing promises.

title: Complicit EP
label: GO4 Music
description: The crassly political EP from Andy Gill struggles to capture the power found in the band’s most potent statements.

title: Lavender
label: Cascine
description: A woozy dynamic of pushing people away while simultaneously drawing them close courses throughout Lavender, a striking album of beautifully rendered and deeply layered synth-pop.

title: Primal Heart
label: Warner Bros.
description: The New Zealand musician’s third album is a collision of hard electronics with a touch of R&B. Though it contains moments of great power, it sounds like a work that’s stuck between two places.

title: Sun Go Nova
label: Mello Music Group
description: Detroit rapper Denmark Vessey lives in the haze. His Sun Go Nova is freewheeling and exciting, the kind of hip-hop that breathes.

title: Stargate Music
artist: Ras G & the Afrikan Space Program
label: Leaving
description: The L.A. beatmaker’s 11th release on Leaving Records moves between wobbly R&B loops, musique concrète, stoned sonic detours, and E.T.-friendly G-funk.

title: KOD
label: Dreamville
description: With his fifth album, the North Carolina rapper aims for righteousness but often ends up sounding self-righteous instead.

title: Eat the Elephant
label: BMG
description: On their first album in 14 years, art-metal giants Maynard James Keenan and Billy Howerdel swerve unexpectedly toward gloomy adult-alternative.

title: Hippo Lite
label: Drag City
description: Cate Le Bon and Tim Presley sound blissfully removed on their second album as a duo, in a quizzical world of their own creation. This one’s best played late at night.

title: Hahaha
label: Exploding in Sound
description: On his first album for Exploding in Sound, this son of Palestinian refugees takes his humanistic blues-folk in a more energetic direction.

title: I, Jonathan
label: Rounder
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the highlight of Jonathan Richman’s rich and varied solo career.

title: Boxer (Live in Brussels)
label: 4AD
description: In 2017, the National revisited their 2007 classic Boxer at a show in Brussels, and the set has been packaged for a Record Store Day release. You had to be there...

title: Bless Yo Trap
label: Alamo
description: Lil Pump’s wingman goes through the motions on an aimless, half-baked new 10-song mixtape with “Nice for What” producer Murda Beatz.

title: When I Think of You in a Castle
label: Polyvinyl
description: This Chicago six-piece plays heavy, proggy psychedelic rock with just the right amount of power-pop sugar to sweeten the mix.

title: Inter-Fusion
label: Cleopatra
description: The L.A. psych-soul artist’s first album in more than 40 years is a plodding, overdriven blues-jazz odyssey that feels like a chore.

title: Beautiful Thing
label: Domino
description: Hot Chip’s singer sounds caught in an irresistible haze on his latest solo LP, making music that’s more deluxe than usual but far scruffier than his main band.

title: Addendum
label: Ribbon Music
description: Presented as a companion piece to last year’s Screen Memories, John Maus’ latest captures the avant-garde artist at his most irreverent and unguarded.

title: ruiner
label: Fueled by Ramen
description: The second album from the promising emo-rap project of Joe Mulherin is sometimes potent, but it buckles from a lack of conviction.

title: Selectors 005
label: Dekmantel
description: The German DJ offers a spellbinding summary of her sound with this compilation of slow, ominous machine grooves. It’s a cross-section of her record collection, but also a map of a community.

title: The ArtScience Remixes EP
label: Blue Note
description: This remix set, based on Glasper’s 2016 album, moves with the freewheeling rhythm of a beat tape. It’s a low-stakes but very fun session.

title: Gada
label: LuckyMe
description: The debut tape from the Montreal vocalist and producer is a daring, eclectic mix of experimental R&B, where intoxicated club nights bleed into sunglasses-and-Advil mornings.

title: Joyride
label: RCA
description: The long-delayed second album from Tinashe includes a handful of bulletproof bops but has arrived as a fragmented vision of the popstar’s many talents.

title: Dimensional People
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Mouse on Mars’ latest is a 43-minute suite broken up by short movements featuring a wide array of guests. The duo’s try-anything spirit remains embedded in every note.

title: Aphelion EP
label: Brainfeeder
description: In the big leagues now, one of the architects of lo-fi house tries to class up his goofy name with a four-track EP and a high-def vision.

title: A Girl Cried Red
label: Rough Trade
description: The latest mixtape from Destiny Frasqueri pulls from her love of emo and alt-rock. It’s an underdeveloped but strangely addictive left-turn.

title: Song for Alpha
label: Phantasy
description: Turning away from the mix of big-room energy and outré sounds that marked his debut, the London producer’s surprisingly muted second album is a catch-all for his varied tastes.

title: Roxy - Tonight’s the Night Live
label: Reprise
description: In 1973, Neil Young played the inaugural show at the Los Angeles club, The Roxy. The reissued recording captures a night that turned his famously bracing album into something warmer and vibrant.

title: Let Night Come on Bells End the Day
label: Recital Program
description: Using Mellotron and electric organ, the Canadian minimalist teases echoes of Baroque music and post-rock while honing in on the idea of the drone as a phenomenological, time-bending experience.

title: Capture the Flag
label: Bridge Nine
description: On their second album, they're not so much raging against the machine as blazing through the air that keeps it alive.

title: The Underdog
label: Spinning Top
description: The latest from Tame Impala and Pond’s Jay Watson smooths out the pastiche psych-rock and dials down the eccentricity to create a more seamless song cycle.

title: The Other
label: Sub Pop
description: Kyle Thomas’ fifth album as King Tuff is more fleshed out and lustrous than before, now preoccupied with death, environmental degradation, and technological dependency.

title: Cerebral Hemispheres
label: Alleviated
description: On the first full-length Mr. Fingers album in almost 25 years, Larry Heard attempts to sum up the full range of his interests and talents.

title: Fragmentos EP
label: Mixpak
description: Leaving the grand maximalism of his previous releases behind, the UK producer focuses more on the comedown of heartbreak creating an altogether cathartic dancefloor experience.

title: Challenge Me Foolish
label: Planet Mu
description: Following two previous archival collections, Challenge Me Foolish dusts off unreleased tracks from the late 1990s, when the Planet Mu founder was making breakbeat-laced IDM with a strange sense of humor.

title: The Marshall Mathers LP
label: Aftermath
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore Eminem’s monumental album The Marshall Mathers LP.

title: Songs for Midi EP
label: Warp
description: The London producer’s new instrumental EP is off-kilter, mercurial, and playful, at once a logical extension and a radical departure from his previous work.

title: Connected and Respected
label: Heavy on the Grind
description: E-40 sounds like a resigned elder statesman on his fourth album with cousin B-Legit, and that’s a surprise coming from someone who used to be superhuman.

title: The Invisible Comes to Us
label: Smithsonian Folkways
description: These folklorists and singers take an audacious step forward on album three, subtly pushing at what folk music sounds like and what it can do.

title: Johnny Cash: Forever Words
label: Legacy
description: Cash family and friends, plus Kacey Musgraves, Chris Cornell, Robert Glasper and others, make songs out of the late Man in Black’s poetry.

title: Pinned
label: Dead Oceans
description: The noise-rock band’s fifth album features new voices, new textures, but strikes the same affected pose.

title: Tree of Forgiveness
label: Oh Boy
description: The songwriter’s first album of new music in 13 years is wise and economical. At 71, John Prine is a virtuoso at understatement, finding the joy in the mundane, and writing about what it means to be alive.

title: The Deconstruction
label: E Works
description: On Eels’ 12th album, Mark Everett trots out his reflexive self-loathing and elementary rhyme schemes one more time, with no clear reason why.

title: Personne d’autre
label: Parlophone
description: Her first album since 2012 is a reflective, characteristically elegant session, surveying the singer’s advancing years in calm repose.

title: Universal Love: Wedding Songs Reimagined EP
label: Sony
description: Featuring Bob Dylan, St. Vincent, and Ben Gibbard, the performances here breathe refreshing gay life into old songs, even if it smacks of branded content a little bit.

title: H
label: The Artist
description: Split between hedonism and hardened street anthems, the Mob Figaz rapper’s first album in more than a decade feels like a time capsule of Bay Area hip-hop as it used to be.

title: CARE FOR ME
label: Saba Pivot
description: The grief-stricken Chicago rapper’s latest is a marvel of craft, musicality, and emotion. Through Saba’s inner turmoil, he finds his most powerful and diaristic storytelling.

title: Where We Were Together
label: Damnably
description: These South Korean devotees of the ’90s indie-rock canon make delicate, bruising music about indecision and loneliness (and lots of drinking).

title: Private Stock
label: Sav Cav Music
description: The New Orleans rapper’s latest album is a meditation on the gravest, most tranquil parts of modern American life, marked by moments of trauma and ones of tranquility. Quelle Chris guests on two key tracks.

title: Geography
label: Beyond The Groove
description: The British singer and beatmaker’s largely self-produced debut album is a pleasant, frictionless listen that benefits from his obvious chops but is held back by his risk-averse tendencies.

title: Total Xanarchy
label: Columbia
description: On his debut album, the standard-bearer of the sad-rap movement refuses to reveal much in the way of emotion at all, aside from a kind of sullen, conflicted defiance.

title: Isolation
label: Virgin EMI
description: The debut album from the Colombian-American singer is a world of her own. Her wide range pulls in sounds from reggaetón, funk, and R&B and positions her to become a new gravitational force in pop.

title: Bellowing Sun
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Jaime Fennelly assembles a full-band and a grand vision for his sixth album as Mind Over Mirrors, a complex and beautiful synth-and-drone time warp.

title: Invasion of Privacy
label: Atlantic
description: Cardi B’s remarkable debut places her, without a doubt, in the pantheon of great rappers. It is both brazen and vulnerable, filled with wild amounts of personality, style, and craft.

title: Loud Patterns
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The first full-length album from the British songwriter and producer Kyle Molleson is dark and dissonant, electronic rock that captures the thrum of cities and the solitude of the country.

title: Vacation in Hell
label: Glorious Dead
description: The second studio album from the staunchly insular Brooklyn rap trio is streamlined and crisp, carried by a newfound momentum missing on their debut.

title: Sex & Food
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Ruban Nielson’s mildew-covered fourth record continues UMO’s long journey inward, pinballing between love and indifference, bops and dirges, pop and its opposite.

title: Goat Girl
label: Rough Trade
description: The debut LP from this South London band is absurd, playful, and more than a little unsettling, sounding at times like a less romantic Libertines.

title: The World Is Yours
label: Interscope
description: The young Atlanta rapper argues that he’s made it, but his pro forma trap debut suggests that he’s not quite there yet.

title: Sextape
label: self-released
description: Cameron Mesirow’s intimate new project builds her production around conversations about formative sexual experiences, which run the gamut from humorous to disturbing, and are often both at once.

title: American Recordings
label: American Recordings
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore Johnny Cash’s 1994 comeback American Recordings.

title: You Fucken Sucker
label: Temporary Residence
description: The Books member returns to familiar terrain, but his drifting electronic mood pieces are too often riddled with diaristic scribblings and nihilistic asides that keep the listener at arm’s length.

title: Pain & Pleasure EP
label: Machine Entertainment Group
description: Tink’s first release since leaving Timbaland’s label is a declaration of freedom that leans away from the personal touch of her best work.

title: Hellbender
label: Relapse
description: One of the most underappreciated bands in American rock’n’roll returns after 14 years, still playing as raw, fast, and loud as ever.

title: Moosebumps: An Exploration Into Modern Day Horripilation
label: Bulk
description: With some modern flourishes, Kool Keith, Dan the Automator, and DJ QBert reconvene mostly for a boom-bap throwback to the ill and the grotesque style of their first 1996 outing.

title: Bark Your Head Off, Dog
label: Saddle Creek
description: Led by singer Frances Quinlan and her remarkable songcraft, the Philly band’s third album is warm and spacious, filled with rich stories rendered beautifully in the abstract.

title: The Louder I Call, the Faster It Runs
label: Merge
description: Recording in the duo’s respective hometowns yields Wye Oak’s brightest, most straightforward effort yet, in which the limits of human understanding are a source of fascination, not frustration.

title: Golden
label: BMG
description: You’ve heard sophisti-Kylie, disco Kylie, and Kraftwerk Kylie. On her 14th album, she tries on a new costume: Ready or not, here comes country Kylie.

title: I Don’t Run
label: Mom & Pop
description: The Spanish group’s second album displays the superior songcraft of the band, as vocalists Ana Perrote and Carlotta Cosials wade through love’s messy feelings with confidence and exuberance.

title: Sister Cities
label: Hopeless
description: On their sixth album, the Springsteen of Philly pop-punk and his bandmates look to the world outside their hometown.

title: Virtue
label: Cult
description: The second album from Julian Casablancas and his motley New York band is sludgy, psychedelic sesh that occasionally coheres into surprising moments of clarity and radiance.

title: Liberating Guilt and Fear
label: Get Better
description: The Philadelphia noise-rock band’s new tape is a thrilling rush of punk violence, pop sparkle, art-rock experimentalism—and wild chirping bird noises.

title: Just Cause Y’all Waited
label: Only the Family
description: This mixtape, released after Durk’s departure from Def Jam, is a minor but effective dispatch from one of Chicago’s most compelling narrators.

title: Daphne & Celeste Save The World
label: Balatonic
description: The Y2K-era bubblegum-pop duo team up with Max Tundra for a fun, ambitious, downright bizarre comeback album, their first LP since 2000.

title: Haze
label: Big Crown
description: Three musicians in their early twenties draw on the hedonistic rock'n'roll blueprint of the 1960s and 1970s on their beautiful, dazed debut LP.

title: Everything’s Fine
label: Mello Music Group
description: Part biting satire, part cognitive behavioral therapy, Jean Grae and Quelle Chris’ collaboration is a hilarious, caustic, and gorgeous consideration of what it really means to be “fine” today.

title: Liberty
label: Shadowbox Music
description: On her seventh LP, the Canadian country singer spins a wild, Spaghetti Western-style yarn about heartbreak, revenge, and redemption.

title: Uneven Paths: Deviant Pop From Europe 1980-1991
label: Music From Memory
description: The widespread dissemination of punk’s DIY ethos coincided with an explosion of affordable studio technology, leading to a largely unheralded revolution in home-recorded pop.

title: Warm Bodies
label: Lumpy
description: Olivia Gibb’s messy, experimental garage rock sounds unhinged and strangely human on Warm Bodies’ debut. Come for the unnerving body horror, stay for the fiery guitar solos.

title: My Dear Melancholy,
label: XO
description: The Weeknd’s new six-song EP finds him in limbo between the bleary-eyed vibe of his early mixtapes and the bulletproof pop stylings of his last two albums.

title: The Calling EP
label: Twisted Elegance
description: Following last year’s debut album, the Dutch-Iranian singer continues to mine trip-hop for inspiration, with a voice that evokes the genre’s greats.

title: Czarface Meets Metal Face
label: Get on Down
description: This comic-book crossover between MF DOOM, Wu-Tang’s Inspectah Deck, and Boston duo 7L & Esoteric attempts to evoke the heyday of underground rap, with mixed results.

title: Golden Hour
label: MCA Nashville
description: The mystical grandeur of Golden Hour creates a magnetic effect as Kacey Musgraves sings simply about the world as if she’s the first person to notice, and you’re the first one she’s telling.

title: Expectations
label: EMPIRE
description: Hayley Kiyoko’s ambitious debut is at its best when it’s barbed and confrontational, but the former Disney star is still trying to hone her budding pop star identity.

title: Raw Like Sushi
label: Virgin
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore Neneh Cherry’s explosive pop debut, Raw Like Sushi.

title: Ceremony of Dreams: Studio Sessions & Outtakes, 1972-1977
label: Tompkins Square
description: The unearthing of these odd compositions from the East Coast ambient group creates a three-hour stream of instrumental riches, whether you’re looking to find samples or get lost in a trance.

title: The Messthetics
label: Dischord
description: Bassist Joe Lally and drummer Brendan Canty—the rhythm section of Fugazi—team up with experimental D.C. guitarist Anthony Pirog for an economic, emotionally resonant instrumental power-trio record.

title: No Joy / Sonic Boom EP
label: Joyful Noise
description: The Canadian shoegaze band’s singer teams up with Spaceman 3’s Pete Kember in an attempt to push past their comfort zone into electronic territory.

title: Code Girl
label: Firehouse 12
description: Writing for a five-person group with vocalist Amirtha Kidambi at its center, the composer-guitarist finds fresh inspiration slipping between diverse genres and songwriting modes.

title: Freedom
label: Sacred Bones
description: The fifth album from Damon McMahon is his euphoric breakthrough. Everything feels silvery and romantic, like a hallucination of the classic-rock songbook.

title: Your Queen Is a Reptile
label: Impulse!
description: On this London group’s first LP for Impulse!, saxophonist Shabaka Hutchings uses jazz’s cultural memory as a rich language that informs an entirely new conversation.

title: Collection 1
label: Godd ComplexX
description: The solo debut from this rapper and singer, who’s worked with Usher and Jidenna, unfolds like a shamelessly wild night out, with material highs and emotional lows galore.

title: Gravitational Pull vs. the Desire for an Aquatic Life
label: Kranky
description: The 1996 album, newly reissued, finds the drone duo transitioning from their rough-hewn early phase into a more graceful, wordlessly evocative mode.

title: The Rite of May EP
label: NUXXE
description: MaryLou Mayniel’s latest collection of hazy R&B is full of dewy vocal passages rendered cool and distant by heavy processing that lands in the safe space between accessible and experimental.

title: Vessel
label: Sub Pop
description: On Greta Kline’s third official album, pure love, self-loathing, and taxidermied dogs all find their way into her dazzling world of perennially inspired indie pop.

title: Don Talk
label: Atlantic
description: The Bronx rapper’s latest project reveals little about his persona other than his approach to rapping, which is blunt and functional.

title: Sex & Cigarettes
label: Def Jam
description: The queen of the coy R&B ballad returns for her first solo album in nearly a decade, making only a few concessions to contemporary trends.

title: Edgewood
label: Ear Drummer
description: Newly signed to Mike WiLL’s label, the Atlanta rapper offers an unsparing chronicle of his come-up on this smoky, sinister major-label debut.

title: Paradox (Original Music From the Film)
label: Reprise
description: The soundtrack to this largely incoherent film achieves a shaky sense of grace thanks to the dusty music from Neil Young and his backing band, Promise of the Real.

title: The Four Worlds
label: Warp
description: Stepping back from the clubbier styles he’s best known for, the prolific electronic polymath turns his attentions to a moody ambient album that shows remarkable restraint.

title: Isle of Dogs (Original Soundtrack)
label: ABKCO
description: The soundtrack to Wes Anderson’s new stop-motion film, built around Alexandre Desplat’s instrumental score, embodies the movie’s spirit of cherishing rather than fearing difference.

title: Blueprint
label: Don Giovanni
description: On her second solo album, the trailblazing punk and Chicana icon sketches a new route forward from her 1970s roots.

title: The Kids Are Alright
label: Parkwood
description: The Beyoncé-approved sister act are fearless on their debut album, reshaping pop and R&B in their own images until even the highest-profile co-signs seem beside the point.

title: 01DEAS
label: R&S
description: Ayman Rostom’s debut album under his house music alias covers a surprisingly large amount of ground with lumbering grooves, off-kilter rhythms, and impish sample play.

title: The Final Tour: The Bootleg Series, Vol. 6
label: Columbia Legacy
description: The audible friction between Davis and Coltrane on almost every number of this four-disc set makes for a fascinating listen, a live document of two players undergoing tectonic shifts in their style.

title: Twentytwo in Blue
label: Mom & Pop
description: The Brooklyn band’s second album offers a reverent spin on the alt and indie-rock canon. Their songwriting has grown tighter since their debut, but their music is unlikely to inspire strong emotions.

title: California EP
label: Mad Decent
description: Plot twist: Diplo’s star-studded new EP will not make you twerk, but it might make you cry.

title: 2 Tone
label: Birdwatcher Records
description: The avant-garde composer and the tabla master orchestrate a controlled collision of their approaches, with harmonious results.

title: Something Else
label: Pye
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore the Kinks’ wistful 1967 classic Something Else.

title: Deep Soundscapes
label: Love Potion
description: Active since the 1990s, the Japanese producer is enjoying a rising profile in the West. His dreamy new album celebrates the synergy between humans and machines.

title: Hormone Lemonade
label: Duophonic
description: Jamming and overdubbing on top of band member Holger Zapf’s experiments with self-constructed drum machines, Cavern of Anti-Matter deliver their most rhythmically intensive record yet.

title: Cardamom Garden EP
label: Modern Sky Entertainment
description: Delving deeper into their lead singer’s Iranian-American roots, the band melds Farsi lyrics with shades of the Beach Boys and the Shangri-Las.

title: Boarding House Reach
label: Third Man
description: With the joy and wit all but absent from his songwriting, Jack White’s third solo album becomes a long, bewildering slog.

title: Longwave
label: Woodsist
description: The Detroit band brings a light touch to the melancholic alt-country songs on this album, which emerged from a spontaneous session in the woods.

title: Music and Poetry of the Kesh
label: Freedom to Spend
description: In 1985, the esteemed novelist worked with composer Todd Barton to create an album of unheard language and instruments. The reissue highlights the rich, totally immersive art Ursula K. Le Guin sought to create.

title: New Material
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The band’s third full-length is an easier and more melodic entry into their spindly post-punk. Here, their defeatism takes on a new tenor: battle-worn, sincere, and not quite so antagonistic.

title: Elevators: Act I & II
label: Nehruvia LLC
description: The New York rapper reunites with his prodigal mentor, MF DOOM, and forges a new partnership with Kaytranada on his full-length solo debut.

title: PRhyme 2
label: PRhyme
description: On his second LP as a duo with DJ Premier, Royce 5’9” fights mightily to offer more than corny punchlines and pointless bars.

title: Brat Mail
label: Republic
description: Kash Doll’s short, 22-minute album contains a lot of flex, some humility, but feels like a victory lap run before the official race has even started.

title: Rich as in Spirit
label: Motown
description: Quan’s official debut is a triumph of willpower and talent, a detail-oriented collection with immaculate production that rightfully reestablishes his place in rap.

title: No Fool Like an Old Fool
label: Western Vinyl
description: From its muted-color harmonies to its overly padded beats, much of Caroline Sallee’s witty and beautiful second album sounds like it’s trying to hide in plain sight

title: High Maintenance EP
label: Warner Bros.
description: The “ICY GRL” rapper’s debut EP is a low-stakes but gratifying listen, full of witty one-liners and cheeky quotables.

title: A Strange Journey Into the Unimaginable
label: Strange Music
description: The veteran rapper’s latest includes a harrowing look at his personal life buoyed by some lighthearted, throwback fare.

title: Bliss
label: GTR
description: Touching on a variety of extreme-music styles, and sampling from iconic revolutionary thinkers, the Philadelphia grindcore quartet grafts noise onto bull-headed hardcore, to blistering effect.

title: Dog Bless
label: Topshelf
description: One of the last revival-style emo bands standing sings about boredom and getting older on their frankly audacious second album.

title: There’s a Riot Going On
label: Matador
description: Yo La Tengo capture the feeling of post-traumatic calm on their latest album, assuring their status as a wry and comforting cornerstone of indie rock.

title: All That Must Be
label: Domino
description: The UK producer’s second album sounds more ready for the club but features the same neon, wistful, song-centric style as his debut.

title: Consumers Park
label: Nature Sounds
description: The Pro Era lieutenant offers golden-age beats and neighborhood-corner rhymes on his solo debut, with echoes of Biggie Smalls and Phife Dawg.

title: I’ll Be Your Girl
label: Capitol
description: Buoyed by a fresh coat of synths and a streamlined energy, the Decemberists’ latest is a curious middle-of-the-road album, teasing a number of directions without committing to any of them.

title: Long Trax 2
label: Smalltown Supersound
