description: Long, also known as the ambient artist Celer, uses the static meter of deep house to explore themes of inertia and stasis in dance music, politics, and society.

title: Jericho Sirens
label: Sub Pop
description: Teeming with revved-up riffs and apocalyptic imagery, the post-hardcore group’s first album since 2005 reasserts their status as the most merciless band in their scene.

title: Nebraska
label: Columbia
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore the solitary sound of the incomparable Nebraska.

title: Surrender Your Soul
label: Secret Sound Club
description: The Toronto rapper's debut shows off his ridiculously catchy melodies and distinct persona, even as it moves within templates set by his peers.

title: Ventriloquism
label: Naïve
description: Tackling a range of R&B radio hits from the 1980s and 1990s, Meshell Ndegeocello treats the practice of covering another’s songs as an act of intimacy and empathy.

title: The Chocolate Box EP
label: Def Jam
description: Most of the songs on this four-track EP are just fine. One is a boorish, boring misfire that should have stayed in the vault.

title: Romance
label: Joyful Noise
description: The Brooklyn band’s 12th album explores new ground and blossoms within the social, spatial, and economic confines of New York.

title: New Path
label: DFA
description: Inspired by Philip K. Dick’s A Scanner Darkly, the married Montreal duo explore themes of addiction, loss, and identity in cinematically tinged coldwave.

title: The Neighbourhood
label: Columbia
description: The Los Angeles band struggle to find an identity on their third album of dramatic rap-tinged alternative rock.

title: Cocoa Sugar
label: Ninja Tune
description: The latest from the experimental rap trio is chaotic but sleek, a streamlined presentation of the singular style Young Fathers have crafted.

title: Myths 003 EP
label: Mexican Summer
description: The third and best installment of Mexican Summer’s collaborative EP series pairs two soft-focus psychedelic bands to righteous effect.

title: Now Only
label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
description: The expansive companion album to last year’s A Crow Looked At Me is no less a marvel. Phil Elverum’s latest is part memoir and part magnum opus, sung softly and with wonder.

title: The Wolf of Grape Street
label: Alamo
description: The latest collection from the Watts rapper is an essential piece of West Coast rap, at times pulsating and manic, born from a singular writer and chameleonic stylist.

title: Communion
label: Mirrorball
description: Blending traditional Korean instruments with woodwinds and mallets, the South Korean composer strikes a captivating balance between minimalism and improvised music.

title: Bobby Tarantino II
label: Def Jam
description: Logic’s latest mixtape is blessedly lighter on its toes and more entertaining than his overambitious albums, doing far more with far less.

title: LONER
label: New West
description: On her self-assured second album, this singer-songwriter uses her mordant wit to confront serious subjects, exorcising trauma with hooks and humor.

title: Francis Trouble
label: Red Bull
description: The guitarist continues his 2010s hot streak with some of the brightest, scrappiest music he’s ever made as a solo artist.

title: You Were Never Really Here (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Lakeshore
description: The prolific composer and Radiohead member crafts a diverse, dissonant, and beat-heavy score that matches the alternate realities of Lynne Ramsay’s psychological thriller.

title: August Greene
label: August Greene, LLC
description: Common teams with Karriem Riggins and Robert Glasper for an album whose best moments suggest a dignified, modern maturation.

title: Have fun EP
label: XL
description: The array of sound and style on the Norwegian duo’s latest EP is engrossing, the sound of off-kilter future-pop composed with equal amounts of sugar and existential dread.

title: Crânio EP
label: Warp
description: For his first release on Warp, the batida and electronic musician puts forth his own meticulous, otherworldly sound and reconnects with the avant-dance spirit of the label’s early years.

title: White Is Relic/Irrealis Mood
label: Polyvinyl
description: Citing influences from DJ Screw to James Baldwin, Kevin Barnes’ latest is a maximalist dance party about our simulated realities.

title: GVVVV
label: CRZKNY
description: An eclectic star of the Japanese beat scene tilts toward the aggressive spirit of gabber and hardcore, largely leaving behind the stylistic markers of footwork.

title: Spiritual Conversations EP
label: Mozzy
description: The Sacramento rapper’s six-song EP brings his themes of psychological trauma to the foreground, suggesting alternate readings of his previous work.

title: Eucalyptus EP
label: Club Chai
description: On their debut EP, and the third release from Oakland’s Club Chai, 8ULENTINA channels breakbeats, synths, and recorded objects into an unusual kind of dancefloor interiority.

title: American Utopia
label: Nonesuch
description: David Byrne’s first true solo album in 14 years is daring and open-hearted. The risks Byrne takes on these songs, however, too often feel clumsy or gaudy.

title: I Need to Start a Garden
label: Mama Bird
description: On her debut LP, the Portland songwriter turns her incisive gaze inward, writing from the feelings in her heart and the visions in her head.

title: Path
label: Terrible
description: The Brooklyn noise musician Will Kraus makes one person sound like a fully staffed shoegaze band, adding new personality to a storied genre.

title: Get Up With It
label: Columbia
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore 1974’s black funk dreamscape from Miles Davis.

title: I’m Bad Now
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: The Nova Scotia quartet’s chilled-out, endearing indie rock gets a slightly more cutting edge on on their third album.

title: Everything Was Beautiful, and Nothing Hurt
label: Little Idiot
description: With a long list of guest vocalists, Moby’s latest more melancholy album is lush but feels anemic and minor compared to some of his best work.

title: Whistle Down the Wind
label: Proper
description: On her first album in a decade, the folk great takes a hard look at the state of the world and tries to muster something like hope.

title: Riddles
label: Carpark
description: The noisy Baltimore post-punk duo team up with Dan Deacon for an album of ’80s pop melodies and newfound lyrical maturity.

title: Lil Boat 2
label: Quality Control

title: OMGRONNY
label: Independently Popular
description: On his major-label debut, SoundCloud rap architect Ronny J showcases his talents as a producer, songwriter, and rapper, with assists from Denzel Curry, Smokepurpp, and XXXTentacion.

title: Corpse Fortress
label: Relapse
description: The Maryland sludge-doom band’s latest album (and first for Relapse Records) is a downright lethal—and impressively inclusive—listen.

title: GOOD Job, You Found Me EP
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: The self-taught Chicago polymath follows his own odd muse on his GOOD Music debut, whispering consumerist sweet nothings over sparse, menacing beats.

title: You’re Not Alone
label: Sony
description: On his first album in nine years, the zen party master uses his operatically excessive music to challenge you to give in to positivity and get over yourself.

title: Feeling EP
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Singer and composer Jenny Hval and multi-instrumentalist Håvard Volden collaborate for an EP of two extended, lucid, and intimate pieces of art-punk.

title: Álbum Desconhecido
label: Príncipe Discos
description: The young, Manchester-based Portuguese producer offers a radical take on batida that draws on the scrappy aggression of UK bass and experimental electro-R&B.

title: Memories Don’t Die

title: RR2: The Bitter Dose
label: Marci Enterprises
description: The Long Island rapper’s latest is a restatement of his core principles, recited in the hallowed style of a religious scripture.

title: How to Socialise & Make Friends
label: Run for Cover

title: Historian
label: Matador
description: On her second album, the Virginia songwriter doesn’t merely reckon with loss; she tells a story about the way people carry each other through time.

title: A Productive Cough
label: Merge

title: Black Times
label: Strut

title: Record
label: Merge
description: On one of the defining albums of her 38-year career, the Everything But the Girl singer embraces her inner disco maven in pursuit of freedom from society’s ordained roles for women.

title: Still Trippin’
label: Hyperdub
description: Infused with his own rapping, the debut album from Teklife’s youngest member makes a strong case for the way footwork has been strengthened, not diluted, as its form has loosened up.

title: Who Are You
label: Beats in Space
description: L.A. musician Eddie Ruscha’s new synth-music project draws on Balearic beat and ambient pop for a concise, easygoing listen.

title: Drift
label: Sacred Bones
description: After a stressful period of reinvention, the band frolics in greener grass, following its wandering muse wherever it leads.

title: Clean
label: Fat Possum
description: Sophie Allison’s excellent studio debut is a compact album of clear melodies, plainspoken lyrics, and the impossibly tangled logic of infatuation.

title: The Diary
label: Rap-A-Lot
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we explore Scarface’s deathly personal 1994 solo album.

title: Felt
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The latest from the gothic avant-rock band sees the four-piece loosen up and let slip the forces begging for release since their debut.

title: Once EP
label: Ninja Tune
description: The South Korea-born, Berlin-based producer is an expert navigator of the balancing act required to make great house music.

title: Tahoe
label: Kranky
description: Erstwhile hip-hop beatmaker Lee Bannon fully embraces ambient music’s conventions on an album that shifts between placid states and disquiet.

title: Superorganism
label: Domino
description: The debut from the UK collective is a hugely accomplished reflection of the present, a magpie-friendly collage of pop all glued together by the laconic voice of Orono Noguchi.

title: Stone Woman EP
label: self-released
description: The Toronto R&B singer’s second EP charts the collapse of a relationship through six downcast tracks.

title: All Nerve
label: 4AD
description: The Breeders’ new album features their iconic Last Splash lineup. It is smoothly confident with many moments of bliss, even as the lyrics evoke isolation, frustration, and scuzz.

title: WWW.
label: American
description: On the Chicago rapper’s latest album, it’s hard to tell whether he is a talented guy who’s just not working hard or a hack with an extraordinary work ethic.

title: Worldwide Angel
label: Puro
description: The Barcelona singer sticks to her synth-heavy, sticky-sweet sound on an album that’s meant to signal her arrival as a global force.

title: This Is Eggland
label: self-released
description: The UK duo’s fifth album, produced by Dave Fridmann, is as good an introduction as you’ll get to their charmingly skewed perspective on the world

title: Time & Space
label: Roadrunner
description: The “experimentation” on the Baltimore band’s latest album is hesitant and unfocused. It’s a punishingly familiar collision of yesteryear's crossover rock with textbook hardcore bluster.

title: Basic Behaviour
label: Arts & Crafts
description: This Toronto band’s best songs have just the right amount of rage to get them out of the shadows of PJ Harvey and Sonic Youth.

title: In Tongues EP
label: 88rising
description: The former YouTube star’s debut album establishes a decent R&B mood but proceeds to wallow in thin, underdeveloped emotions.

title: Smell Smoke
label: Gawk
description: The Boston indie rock band craft a winning, cathartic record about grief, capitalism, and all the stuff we leave behind.

title: async remodels
label: Milan
description: A varied group of remixers tackles the Japanese composer’s 2017 album async, but despite a few standouts, the collection lacks the stark force of the original.

title: Three/Three
label: Ghostly International
description: The Michigan electronic hip-hop producer returns to his best-known project after a decade-plus break. With Danny Brown, MF DOOM, and more.

title: Hundred Acres
label: Jagjaguwar
description: As his solo career gains momentum, the second-most famous member of Bon Iver spends his latest LP meditating on the simple life.

title: FEVER
label: Computer Ugly
description: The Detroit rapper/producer follows up the instrumental The Rebellion Sessions with a solo rap record that confirms him as a serviceable emcee—and a session leader with a sense of purpose.

title: Language
label: Ghostly International
description: Bryndon Cook is a hired gun for Solange, Chairlift, and Blood Orange; his debut album is a slick, colorful foray into retro-futurist funk that’s fueled by his keen sense of style.

title: Lo Moon
label: Columbia
description: The L.A. band behind 2016’s slow-burning single “Loveless” turns in a perilously top-heavy debut album.

title: Gangin
label: SOB X RBE
description: The four-man Bay Area rap crew delivers a breathless, irresistible, and highly defined record that hits your gut and your shoulders at the same time.

title: Witness Marks: The Works of John B. McLemore
label: Dais
description: The posthumous ambient music of the mercurial genius featured on “S-Town” is a peek into the sounds of his quiet and fascinating life.

title: 40oz. to Freedom
label: Skunk
description: The debut album from the SoCal trio is a flawed artifact of ’90s alt-rock, punk, ska, and hip-hop, but remains a fascinating document of Bradley Nowell as the honey-voiced musical tourist bro.

title: Lala Belu
label: Awesome Tapes From Africa
description: The Ethiopian keyboard maestro’s first new album in two decades radically updates a style that already sounded like the future.

title: Victory Lap
label: All Money In
description: The long-awaited debut from the Los Angeles rapper cashes in on its promise. It’s the most gripping record in his catalog.

title: Gemini II
label: Spirit House
description: Warren’s complex, unwinding melodies shine on her latest album, and while the concept views love through an astrological lens, the lyrics expose life’s crushing banality.

title: Game Winner EP
label: Secretly Canadian
description: This L.A. funk and soul musician, known as a member of Vulfpeck, meanders through a handful of solo joints about love and basketball.

title: 2 Heartless
label: N-Less
description: A revelation hidden in plain sight, this Memphis rapper’s latest project is more proof that he’s headed for bigger things.

title: Kyoto
label: Last Kings
description: The Los Angeles rapper’s latest career move is a pleading, quasi-introspective R&B album that suffers from an almost total lack of imagination.

title: Reachin’ (A New Refutation of Time and Space)
label: Light in the Attic
description: The jazz rap trio’s 1993 debut questions the very fabric of our existence while celebrating its nuances.

title: All at Once
label: Don Giovanni
description: The New Jersey band’s seventh album tilts toward pop-punk, modern rock, and more, with a guest turn from Fugazi’s Brendan Canty.

title: Heart Break Kodak
label: Atlantic
description: On his so-called R&B album, it’s exceedingly difficult to square the real-life allegations of the Florida rapper with the toxic content of his songs.

title: Black Panther (Original Score)
label: Marvel Music
description: Ludwig Göransson’s spectacular score captures the multiplicity of the fictional nation of Wakanda.

title: Loma
label: Sub Pop
description: Shearwater’s Jonathan Meiburg teams up with the duo Cross Record on a slowcore-influenced album enlivened by a surprising musical chemistry.

title: American Nightmare
label: Rise
description: The prodigal trailblazers of Boston hardcore have reunited, returned, and evolved with their first album in 15 years.

title: Last Night All My Dreams Came True
label: Domino Documents
description: Wild Beasts bid fans farewell by revisiting their catalog in a collection of live studio takes. It’s not an entirely satisfying goodbye, but it’s a faithful snapshot of a band always in motion.

title: How to Solve Our Human Problems, Pt. 3
label: Matador
description: After brushes with extroversion, the final installment of their EP series finds singers Sarah Martin and Stuart Murdoch turning inward with songs that take you inside its characters’ private lives.

title: Everything Is Recorded by Richard Russell
label: XL
description: The new project from the head of XL Recordings features collaborations with Sampha, Kamasi Washington, and Ghostface Killah’s son.

title: What a Time to Be Alive
label: Merge

title: Tomorrow’s Shore EP
label: Wichita

title: In a Poem Unlimited
label: 4AD

title: Dear Annie
label: 300 Entertainment
description: This Irish rapper's debut suggests great potential, even if he's limited for now by the obvious influence of N.E.R.D and Tyler, the Creator.

title: Room Inside the World
label: Merge
description: Ought’s third album straightens out their sound, offering a more refined new wave palette underneath their singular and compelling lyrical style.

title: A Whole Fucking Lifetime of This
label: Run for Cover
description: The band formerly known as Teen Suicide has a fresh outlook on life. Their new album might be the best thing frontman Sam Ray has made so far.

title: The Boy With the Arab Strap
label: Jeepster
description: The Scottish band’s excellent third album features some of their darkest and most detailed songs. Wholly beautiful and delicate, it was Stuart Murdoch’s first reluctant step into the spotlight.

title: By the Way, I Forgive You
label: Elektra
description: Carlile’s sixth LP is a move toward her prestige era, a moment when she’s expected to reconcile the warring parts of herself for a growing audience.

title: Sir
label: Ultra
description: The electroclash duo returns from a nine-year hiatus with a new creative brain trust in tow, but a few standout singles aren’t enough to redeem a plodding, repetitive album.

title: Few Traces
label: Rvng Intl.
description: A new reissue resurfaces the music of a cult-favorite songwriter from 1980s Baltimore who drew on ambient and British pop influences.

title: Way Out West
label: Craft
description: Recorded in Los Angeles in 1957, the jazz legend’s classic album—the first to use the now-standard saxophone-bass-drums trio—looks like a novelty and sounds like transcendence.

title: Twin Fantasy
label: Matador

title: Brighter Wounds
label: City Slang
description: On the synth-rock project’s fifth album, the stakes feel higher, with new fatherhood and the perilous state of the world inspiring searching introspection and dramatic gestures.

title: Wait for Love
label: Epitaph
description: The intensely serious post-hardcore band marks the turn from death and loss to life and love with nimble musicianship, inventive rhythms, and Kyle Durfey’s most accomplished singing yet.

title: Travels in Constants EP
label: Temporary Residence

title: The Secret Life of Planets
label: self-released
description: Zaki Ibrahim’s second album is a future-soul marvel that connects sounds across time and oceans, creating thrilling moments of pop music synthesized through her wise and worldly vision.

title: Unsolved Mysteries
label: Ultramajic
description: Discovered gathering dust in an old storage unit, the Detroit artist’s lost album from the ’90s is an interesting curio that slots nicely alongside techno’s current renaissance.

title: Effected
label: Dreamville
description: For his second album on J. Cole’s imprint, Cozz is beginning to build his own style while finding how to maneuver between the boisterous and introspective.

title: Music for the Long Emergency
label: Totally Gross National Product
description: The Minneapolis synth-pop band teams up with a Berlin-based orchestra in an attempt to reckon with the trials of our time.

title: Cranberry
label: Double Double Whammy
description: The Austin indie-pop duo’s music conjures a steady, gentle longing. Foggy, warm, and wistful, it sounds like faded time.

title: Slow Sundown
label: Wharf Cat
description: This Estonian band’s debut album sounds like a long, lonely drive on a moonlit night, with plenty of guitar reverb.

title: Order of Torment
label: Relapse
description: The D.C. death metal band attacks with pummeling force and socially pointed lyrics, in the tradition of Bolt Thrower and Incantation.

title: Tongue
label: Friends of Friends
description: The Los Angeles-based producer retreats to the hills of Tuscany to further the vision of eclectic mix of woodwinds, synthesizers, and field recordings.

title: Crush EP
label: Atlantic
description: The Chicago R&B upstart pairs with producer Steve Lacy for five tracks of inventive modernist soul.

title: High Rise II
label: Black Editions
description: Originally released in 1986, the reissue of High Rise II shines a light on an important and fiery document of Japanese psych rock.

title: Cloud 909
label: Good Vibe Tribe
description: The duo’s grab-bag approach continues on their third studio album, an 18-track marathon with more good than bad but little of substance.

title: Dead Start Program
label: Kompakt
description: The Los Angeles producer’s house and techno is hyper-attuned to the nuances of timbre, giving his music a captivating textural focus even when emotion is in scant supply.

title: Transangelic Exodus
label: Bella Union
description: The singer-songwriter’s latest album features a sweeping backstory about supernatural queer lovers on the run and a lurid, cinematic new sound.

title: Stankonia
label: La Face
description: What could’ve been a victory lap for two Southern rappers on top of the game was instead a transcendental funk fantasia, an unequivocal commercial and artistic triumph.

title: Posthuman
label: Metal Blade
description: The swole Chicago hardcore band’s latest album shows their raw strength while adding shades of industrial and groove metal for character.

title: Crooked Shadows
label: Fueled by Ramen
description: The emo lifer’s seventh album tries to balance intimacy and accessibility, but he only ends up with the latter.

title: Go Dig My Grave
label: SusannaSonata
description: The Norwegian vocalist offers spare, chilly covers of songs from post-punk Manchester, 1970s New York, and Elizabethan England.

title: How to Measure the Distance Between Lovers EP
label: never_b_alone.mp3
description: The rising EDM star swerves left on an insular, personal record that's more suited for winding down than turning up.

title: Rock Island
label: Carpark
description: On their second album, the wildly inventive art-rock band works harder than ever to unburden itself of the influences heard in its earlier work.

title: The Two Worlds
label: Tompkins Square
description: The second album from the singer-songwriter is a dizzyingly isolated record, spare and serene music that gains momentum as it burrows deeper.

title: Little Dark Age
label: Columbia
description: MGMT’s fourth album marks a shift in tactics. Abandoning the belabored excess of their last two albums, they opt for streamlined synth-pop.

title: Drip Season 3
label: YSL
description: This Young Thug protégé’s latest mixtape locks in on a vibe and rolls wherever it goes. Usually it doesn’t go too far.

title: Dream Wife
label: Lucky Number
description: The UK rock band’s debut is a prime example of what happens when you grow up on Bikini Kill and the Slits.

title: Always Ascending
label: Domino
description: At its best, the fifth album from the UK indie-rock stalwarts is sleek, catchy, and enjoyably overwrought, the sound of a snappy hype band no longer burdened by relevance.

title: Metal Aether
label: NNA Tapes
description: The New York composer is an electro-acoustic minimalist who pays special attention to the spaces around her. Her latest album, by turns grounded and disquieting, feels untethered and limitless.

title: Pissing Stars
label: Constellation
description: The Godspeed You! Black Emperor co-founder’s second album searches for love in the middle of a hellscape, with surprising shades of Springsteen.

title: Criminal
label: Sacred Bones
description: On his fourth album as the Soft Moon, post-punk auteur Luis Vasquez finally breaks from a whisper into a scream.

title: If You’re Into It, I’m Out of It
label: Cross Fade Entertainment
description: Originally released in 1997, the German producer’s world of mythic drones and breakbeats is newly remastered and remains a blistering and confrontational touchstone of electronic music.

title: There Will Be Rain
label: Grand Closing
description: The Bronx rapper’s second solo album grapples with questions of faith over jazz and gospel production.

title: Early Tape Works (1986-1993) Vol.1

description: Produced using analog synths, drum machines, and four-track tape, these ambient sketches and beat experiments reveal the foundations of the Japanese producer’s later, more elaborate work.

title: Amen
label: EMPIRE

title: The Book Room

title: ION

title: Mitteltöner
label: Origin Peoples

title: Full Circle Nightmare
label: Sub Pop
description: This Portland songwriter’s second album is full of femme fatales and other clichés dredged from a half-century of classic rock.

title: Microshift
label: Domino
description: The English psych-punks turn down the distortion and face their demons with a new, synth-y sound on their third album.

title: Island Universe Story Four
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Roberto Lange’s fourth installment in his Island Universe series contains subconscious whisperings that provide a map for the music he’s been making as Helado Negro for the last eight years.

title: Blood
label: Loma Vista
description: The second album from Michael Milosh and his soft-rock musicians deftly creates an atmosphere that builds out their sound without adding much underneath.

title: Quit the Curse
label: Polyvinyl
description: On her solo debut, the Detroit singer-songwriter cuts with her folk-rock past and turns to 1960s-indebted indie pop and 1990s-schooled alt-rock hooks.

title: Cosmic Crypt
label: Relapse
description: Austin musician Chris Ulsh’s longest-running band returns with a revitalized lineup and a new commitment to death metal intensity.

title: Pulse/Quartet
label: Nonesuch
description: Though detailed and accomplished, Steve Reich’s latest work dully reaffirms his place as a centrist in a field of extremists.

title: Outside
label: Atlantic
description: Following an all-too-brief turn on Drake’s More Life, one of Nigeria’s preeminent musical ambassadors shares his own hybrid vision, drawing on Afrobeats, dancehall, and road rap.

title: Man of the Woods
label: RCA
description: Justin Timberlake’s fifth album is a huge misstep for the pop star. It is warm, indulgent, inert, and vacuous.

title: Lionheart
label: Merge
description: Released on Merge Records, the singer-songwriter’s debut is a gorgeous devotional to the South that reshapes the traditions of country music into a powerfully queer and consequential set of songs.

title: Open Here
label: Memphis Industries
description: The UK art-rock duo’s new album has the earnest directness of artists whose sense of the world has been nudged into focus.

title: Follow Them True
label: From Here
description: Respecting folk music’s past while uprooting it from the pastoral, the UK group’s politically minded album mixes acoustic and electronic instruments across original songs and traditionals.

title: Con Todo El Mundo
label: Night Time Stories Ltd.
description: On their second album, the Houston-based instrumental trio crafts a unique, psychedelic vibe that hangs between continents and eras.

title: Slow Fade EP
label: Phantasy
description: The UK producer expands into ambient territory, finding drama in negative spaces and downtempo explorations.

title: Impossible Star
label: self-released
description: Influential sample maestro Jack Dangers’ first album since 2010 is a moody, playful exhibition of his strengths.

title: Veteran

description: The 28-year-old rapper’s latest album is a glitchy, frantic, confrontational album on both a musical and political level. It feels born of an internet wasteland.

title: Young & Reckless
label: 300 Entertainment
description: On an unexpected collaborative mixtape, the two previously unconnected rappers hone their complementary styles in gloomy songs shot through with paranoia.

title: Oh My
label: Father/Daughter
description: On their debut as a trio, Phantom Posse singer-songwriter Nadia Hulett and members of Ava Luna play with open-ended questions and experimental pop zest.

title: Culture II
label: Quality Control
description: Where Culture was an event, its follow-up feels more like an occurrence, the quality of its songs handicapped by an album that plays like a long and formless grab bag.

title: Love Jail
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The trio’s second album buffs away some of its debut’s grime and distortion for a set of knotty, pummeling rock that sounds vintage but feels current.

title: Big Bossin Vol. 2
label: Def Jam
description: The Detroit rapper and the Dallas producer team up for another satin-smooth album of street hustler stories.

title: Pèze-Piton
label: 12th Isle
description: Mixing up elements of kuduro, dancehall, baile funk, and other global sounds, the Berlin-based producer channels the sound of traveling with no fixed destination in mind.

title: Could It Be Different?
label: Slumberland
description: The idealistic, politically-minded Scottish indie-pop band gloss up their sound on album three.

title: The Brown Tape
label: Mello Music Group
description: An alternate version of Ghostface’s 2013 album 12 Reasons to Die, produced by Detroit’s Apollo Brown, features beats that suit the rapper’s strengths more closely.

title: Snares Like a Haircut
label: Drag City
description: The noise-rock duo’s fifth album is a fresh and clear-eyed statement, drawing most from punk’s impulse towards attentiveness and honesty.

title: All Eyez on Me
label: Death Row
description: Tupac’s 1996 double album was made in a frenzy. It is paranoid and brazen, fun and fearless, but it is Pac’s singular style that keeps one of his greatest records from coming undone at the seams.

title: Vessel of Love
label: Merge
description: On her pristine third album, Hollie Cook, a UK singer and one-time Slits member, draws upon 1970s reggae in songs about love and resilience.

title: Fleetwood Mac
label: Warner Bros.
description: Though far from their debut, the band’s 1975 self-titled album felt like a debut: a pop-rock statement and the unexpected intersection of two parallel spheres that offered something genuinely new.

title: More Disco Songs About Love
label: Innovative Leisure
description: The sort-of disco duo has got the hooks and the groove but on their third album, they struggle to find their footing.

title: Weather or Not
label: Rhymesayers
description: The Dilated Peoples MC’s third solo album shows his continued faith in the eternal truths of boom-bap rap music.

title: Freedom’s Goblin
label: Drag City
description: On his excellent and ambitious double album, the tuneful sensibility that Segall has been nurturing for years has fully blossomed, all while keeping his primordial spirit intact.

title: The Thread That Keeps Us
label: Anti-
description: The reliable Southwestern indie-rockers’ ninth album is full of impassioned stories about border politics and environmental disasters.

title: The Time Is Now
label: Insanity
description: A veteran of UK garage and R&B, Craig David follows up his 2016 comeback by fishing for current trends to keep him relevant.

title: Down Below
label: Century Media
description: Traditionalists no more, the Swedish band spend their fourth album exploring the divide between metal’s underground and mainstream.

title: Digital Rain
label: ITALIANS DO IT BETTER
description: The latest solo album from the leader of Chromatics is a full-scale concept album about inclement weather.

title: Marble Skies
label: Ribbon Music
description: The mad scientists of UK psych-rock take an unexpected turn toward pop on their third album.

title: Un Peu De L’Âme Des Bandits
label: Crammed Discs
description: Originally released in 1980, the newly reissued second album from the Belgian art-rockers is a knotty experiment that freely slams together the sounds of contemporary classical music and free jazz.

title: All Melody
label: Erased Tapes
description: Recorded in the storied Funkhaus studio in Germany, All Melody is pianist Nils Frahm’s grandest statement yet, yet it maintains the inquisitive, exploratory spirit of his most playful recordings.

title: what people call low self​-​esteem is really just seeing yourself the way that other people see you
label: self-released
description: The San Jose emo band’s debut sounds like various states of alarm, a big statement that leans on the raw impulses of singer and songwriter Shannon Taylor.

title: I Can Feel You Creep Into My Private Life
label: 4AD
description: On her confrontational fourth album, Merrill Garbus wades into the politics of being white in America. It is musically and lyrically ambitious, but its grander themes land with an uncomfortable thud.

title: The Worm’s Heart
label: Columbia
description: James Mercer takes his most recent album through the looking glass, flipping songs’ tempos and production styles on an eccentric mission of discovery.

title: LiE
label: Sub Pop
description: The grunge survivors leap back into the moshpit of time on a live album culled from their 2016 tour of Europe.

title: Chris Dave and the Drumhedz
label: Blue Note
description: Though its many guest vocalists can be distracting, the Houston-born musician’s debut album presents a strong argument for the drummer as a modern bandleader.

title: The House
label: Domino
description: The New York-based songwriter Aaron Maine stays in the lane of writing delicate, evocative songs with homespun beats, but he never quite locks into the kind of groove that made his last record Pool so satisfying.

title: Cadence Weapon
label: eOne
description: The rapper and former Edmonton poet laureate’s first album in six years unpacks his history as a hip-hop advocate and explores the inner workings of Canadian beat communities.

title: Blue Madonna
label: Interscope
description: The second album from the rapidly ascending synth-pop artist Garrett Borns offers more of the same: great ideas constrained in songs that rarely allow them to come to fruition.

title: Between Two Shores
label: Anti-
description: On his latest solo album, the Irish folk singer sets sail on a journey of the heart, full of sad break-up songs and meandering musings.

title: Time Flying Beats
label: Leaving
description: On his latest album, a luminary of the Los Angeles beat scene remembers how to come back down from the astral plane and hits the dance floor running.

title: Rich Hood
label: EMPIRE
description: Gucci Mane’s latest protégé, a smooth-talking rapper with a nonchalant charm, steps into the spotlight after a streak of well-liked mixtapes.

title: The Official Body
label: Fat Cat
description: The third record from the UK trio wrangles their elastic, post-punk spirit into an urgency that feels bonded to the present. It makes for songs that are as mesmerizing as they are exhilarating.

title: Voice Hardcore
label: Mesh-Key
description: Using mainly her resilient voice and some electronic effects, the latest record from the Japanese underground legend draws parallels to the punk impulse with her extended, avant-garde vocal excursions.

title: Semicircle
label: Memphis Industries
description: On their fifth album, the Go! Team look to the Motor City for their 1960s fix; they’re as boisterous as ever, but their nostalgia doesn’t dip far beneath the surface of their inspirations.

title: Ruins
label: Columbia
description: The Swedish folk duo’s fourth album is a showcase for their sweet harmonies, with some bold stylistic departures.

title: Somewhere Else
label: Wharf Cat
description: On their quietly commanding darkwave record, songwriter Noah Anthony and poet Elaine Kahn use harsh noise and power electronics to show it’s possible to care for chaos.

title: Into One Name
label: Genome 6.66 Mbp
description: On his new album for Shanghai’s Genome Tapes, London’s Tim Zha applies Auto-Tuned vocals to hybrid pop informed by dancehall and Afrobeats, where bright details dance against a blurry backdrop.

title: How to Solve Our Human Problems, Pt. 2
label: Matador
description: Having grown from wise-beyond-their-years aesthetes into middle-aged adults, Belle and Sebastian balance parental sentimentalism with a youthful abandon rarely entertained on their early recordings.

title: November
label: Top Dawg
description: The Inglewood artist’s first album as Kendrick and SZA’s labelmate is a neo-soul-tinged space odyssey about love.

title: Songs of Praise
label: Dead Oceans
description: On their debut album, the UK rock group separates themselves from their peers, imbuing their post-adolescent rage with wit and, crucially, a self-effacing awareness that they may never succeed.

title: Camila
label: Epic
description: The former Fifth Harmony member’s debut solo album is largely successful at capturing her charismatic flair. Anchored by the wonderful “Havana,” it shines especially when it's light and breezy.

title: The Dude
label: Super Audio CD
description: Jones’ all-star pop-soul adventure prefigured Thriller and highlighted his ear for new grooves.

title: Sekundenschlaf
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: A mysterious project from an unknown source sends listeners on an exhilarating goose chase through ambient techno and ethereal jungle.

title: Sun Ra Plays Gershwin
label: Enterplanetary Koncepts
description: A collection of George Gershwin interpretations by the avant-jazz legend traces his roots in the swing era, fleshing out a seldom-heard side of the astral voyager.

title: Vision Songs, Vol. 1
label: Numero Group
description: Numero Group turns up an outlier in the new-age icon’s catalog: an album of vocal music that, while a lesser work, offers a glimpse of a seldom-seen side of Laraaji.

title: Punken
label: TSO
description: The Houston rapper’s first mixtape since 2016 is full of unsparing storytelling, pusher anthems, and a dynamic array of trap production over which Maxo delivers some of his most effective writing.

title: Phantom Thread Original Motion Picture Soundtrack
label: Nonesuch
description: Recorded with a 60-piece orchestra, the Radiohead member’s score for Paul Thomas Anderson’s latest film is as lavish as its high-fashion, old-money backdrop.

title: Gumboot Soup
label: Flightless
description: The Aussie psych-rock group’s fifth album of 2017 is anything but a tossed-off afterthought, showing a new dedication to pop craftsmanship.

title: Life of a Dark Rose
label: self-released
description: The buzzing rapper’s debut mixtape is an easygoing 40 minutes of sugary trap and mellow, blissfully hazy vibe-music that runs with the sounds of the moment without advancing them much.

title: Weekend Rocker
label: Drunken Sailor
description: Halifax punks kick out the jams with plenty of distortion on their exhilaratingly rowdy second full-length.

title: Wrong Creatures
label: Vagrant
description: BRMC’s eighth album continues to prop up the rock-historical establishment. It offers more of the same, but at least it’s more of the same in a fairly compelling way.

title: El Gato: The Human Glacier
label: Atlantic
description: On his sixth album since re-starting his career post-jail, Gucci remains focused, funny, and at the top of his game.

title: No Dogs Allowed
label: self-released
description: This Boston singer-songwriter’s second proper album is a treasure trove of self-deprecating wit, melodic complexity, and endearingly anxious energy.

title: Just for Us
label: KTTF
description: On Francis Starlite’s third album, his music turns spare and stark as he comes closer to his finding his essence as a songwriter.

title: Nasty Gal
label: Light in the Attic
description: 1975’s Nasty Gal is another classic from one of the founders of funk. Davis and her band are a little sleazy, a little sultry, and show some surprising range on an album newly reissued on vinyl.

title: To Infinity
label: Topshelf
description: The Seattle indie rockers’ debut album places them in the lineage of bands like Modest Mouse and Built to Spill, wrapping majestically dejected songwriting in ambitiously atmospheric production.

title: Ephorize
label: self-released
description: The fearless Chicago rapper offers her best album yet, with terrific production and a barrage of raps that reveal Elizabeth Harris to be far more than her hilarious and absurdly raunchy one-liners.

title: Good Job No Conversation
label: Ultra
description: Channeling Sade, covering James Blake, and indulging in some silk-sheets saxophone, the Danish pop producer William Asingh makes a plush, playful, and quietly audacious debut.

title: Hats
label: Linn
description: The Scottish group’s 1989 cult classic is an album of euphoric love and loss that unfolds slowly and with starry eyes. Its noir mood and icy melodrama are still felt all over modern pop.

title: Urge to Merge
label: NNA Tapes
description: The Boston band’s second and final album is a bright explosion in every atonal direction from math-rock breakdowns to sludgy noise, like virtuosos pushing the self-destruct button.

title: Water Memory
label: self-released
description: Across its 40 minutes, the Los Angeles artist builds a modular synth album that is enveloping and cohesive. What initially sounds static may, upon closer examination, reveal a wealth of movement.

title: POST-
label: Quote Unquote
description: The magnetic Jeff Rosenstock stays fully armed with his power-pop anthems, as full of indomitable hooks as they are of paralyzing doubt and cynicism.

title: Cold Devil
label: Stinc Team
description: Cold Devil is the most compelling album of the Los Angeles emcee’s career. His avant deadpan and impressionistic relationship to the beat is hard to classify, but it’s icy and unforgettable.

title: Bright: The Album
label: Atlantic
description: None of the wild imagination fueling David Ayers’ bloated orc cop epic carries over to its soundtrack, which feels test-marketed to a fault.

title: Lady Bird (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Lakeshore
description: Using piano, strings, a wind ensemble, and light percussion, Brion’s score subtly and deftly mirrors the existential ambling of Greta Gerwig’s outstanding coming-of-age film.

title: Trans-Millenia Music
label: Rvng Intl.
description: This anthology of self-released new age music from the 1980s captures a moment of spiritual questing, and it rightly rescues its creator from historical obscurity.

title: Virtual Self EP
label: self-released
description: Adopting a new alias, the EDM producer Porter Robinson sets aside Worlds’ electro-pop crossover and embraces early-2000s trance and video-game music.

title: Ghosts
label: Lewis Hollow
description: The Sunny Day Real Estate singer returns from a long hiatus with a crowd-funded solo album that reconciles his singer/songwriter instincts with his lavish orchestral ambitions.

title: Mercury’s Rainbow
label: Modern Love
description: Both naggingly familiar and singularly odd, Zomby’s previously unreleased 2008 album finds him putting his own quixotic stamp on grime’s classic eskibeat sound.

title: Pressure
label: Def Jam
description: Jeezy is less effective these days, as his new album attests. But he covers gaps in his writing with a few tricks and guest appearances from Kendrick, Rick Ross, YG, 2 Chainz, and others.

title: Quiet Storm
label: 300 Entertainment
description: Capping off his breakout year, the D.C. rapper offers a deft album of soft synths and languid trap that further carves out his identity.

title: The Beautiful & Damned
label: RCA
description: The new album from Oakland rapper G-Eazy is a boozy, minor-key, 74-minute slog, where he wonders if it’s possible to survive the corrupting influence of celebrity.

title: Pop 2
label: Asylum
description: Charli XCX’s latest mixtape is a vision of what pop music could be, the sound of an eclectic, hyperreal future where romantic love is fun but fucked and partying is an emotional refuge.

title: The Golden Ravedays
label: Hippie Dance
description: German producer Aksel Schaufler, aka Superpitcher, has long been a leading light of Cologne’s Kompakt label. His eclectic new solo album renews his commitment to duration—it’s nearly six hours long.

title: Revival
label: Aftermath
description: On his overtly political ninth studio LP, Eminem is fueled by self-doubt. But with many bland hooks and cringe-worthy punchlines, Revival is another late-career album that does little for his legacy.

title: Finding Shore
label: Dead Oceans
description: A collaboration between an improvising pianist and the ambient icon yields an unusual fusion of acoustic and electronic ideas—a meeting of minds that is full of rewarding surprises.

title: Rage Against the Machine
label: Epic
description: Rage Against the Machine’s debut is a radical fistful of funk, rap, and rock. Through its power, it remains an essential call to activism and a necessary lesson on how to withstand the opposition.

title: Diggin’ in the Carts: A Collection of Pioneering Japanese Video Game Music
label: Hyperdub
description: Assembled by Hyperdub’s Steve Goodman and filmmaker Nick Dwyer, this 34-track compilation offers a retro-futurist deep dive into a lost world of incidental music of surprising power and poignancy.

title: Bloodas
label: 300 Entertainment
description: Detroit rapper Tee Grizzley and Chicago drill alum Lil Durk team up for a promising mixtape that showcases their considerable chemistry.

title: Special Forces
label: NNA Tapes
description: The producer known as Ahnnu is affiliated with L.A.’s beat-music scene, but his sounds are swirling and gelatinous. Rhythms never unfold quite the way you might expect them to on his hypnotic new LP.

title: Saturation III
label: EMPIRE
description: It's on their third album this year that rap crew BROCKHAMPTON’s whole gestalt comes into focus. There are more memorable performances, and more fascinatingly unorthodox compositions servicing them.

title: Laughing at the System EP
label: Alter
description: Absurdity is the guiding principle of the new EP from the Australian post-punk band. This delightfully bizarre release distills Total Control’s gnashing, dazzling appeal.

title: My House From All Angles
label: MoreAboutMusic
description: On his first solo LP in 27 years, house producer Mike Dunn celebrates the old school: Acid lines squirm, vintage drum machines knock and thrash, and Dunn holds court with his commanding baritone.

title: Tribute To 2
label: ATO
description: On a sequel to 2009’s covers collection Tribute To, the My Morning Jacket singer imbues a set of classics and standards with a distinctly contemporary melancholy.

label: Showoff
description: Statik Selektah, a hip-hop mainstay, brings Action Bronson, Joey Bada$$, Raekwon, Prodigy and more for a boppy, East Coast delight that doesn't make the best use of the producer’s intuition.

title: Double or Nothing
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: Though fun and at times politically salient, even Metro Boomin cannot rescue Big Sean from his habit of writing the absolute corniest lyrics imaginable.

title: 2 Tha Left
label: So Way Out
description: West Coast rap nostalgist G Perico has spent 2017 on a forward-looking tear. His third full-length release of the year contains his immediate charm.

title: Highly Rare
label: International Anthem
description: Recorded live in Chicago and then rearranged in the drummer/producer’s studio, Highly Rare channels an electric night of raw improv into a shapeshifting form halfway between hip-hop and free jazz.

title: Universel
label: Melody As Truth
description: The latest from prolific Danish producer Natal Zaks is a short album of blissed-out, ambient textures, but is no less immersive thanks to his deft sense of world-building.

title: Too Hard
label: Quality Control
description: The Atlanta rapper is slowly coming into his own as a Young Thug disciple with an intrinsic tunefulness and strong storytelling that is marred by the undistinguished Quality Control production.

title: Habibi Funk: An Eclectic Selection of Music From the Arab World
label: Habibi Funk Records
description: A new compilation from Habibi Funk records highlights the old and interweaving sounds of Algerian coladera, Lebanese AOR, Egyptian disco, Moroccan funk and more.

title: Dedication
label: Glo Gang
description: Balancing his characteristic humor with newfound vulnerability, Keef’s latest is a worthy capstone to a prolific year in which the Chicago rapper has resurrected his reputation and career.

title: Perfect Lung
label: Halocline Trance
description: On his latest LP, the producer Ceramic TL (aka Egyptrixx) collaborates with Turkish composer Ipek Gorgun on another heady investigation of the global environmental crisis.

title: Daydream
label: Columbia
description: On 1995’s Daydream, the spectacular pop vocalist fine-tuned her songcraft. The album redrew the boundaries of what a Mariah Carey song—and a pop song—was supposed to sound like.

title: Lex
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Augmenting electro-acoustic fusions with speech synthesis and language translation software, Visible Cloaks invoke mystifying new form of dialects and communication on their mini-LP.

title: Book of Sound
label: Honest Jon's
description: On their latest album, the ensemble that made their name in scrappy performances on the sidewalks and street corners of New York City and Chicago turns muted, spare, warm and still.

title: KIMBERLY: The People I Used to Know
label: Atlantic
description: The singer, reality star, and social-media icon is joyous and defiant, projecting realness and flaunting considerable vocal chops.

title: Kingdoms Disdained
label: Silver Lining
description: Morbid Angel’s ninth album sets the death metal band back on course. Featuring Trey Azagthoth’s molten solos, the band rediscover what they did well across their career and double down on it.

title: Catch These Vibes
label: Atlantic
description: On the young singer’s second major label album, PnB struggles to push past the boundaries of his previous work, but with a few solid tunes, it shows him finding his way in the major-label apparatus.

title: No Shame
label: 300 Entertainment
description: On his corrosive fifth album, the rapper takes aim at several targets and whiffs spectacularly. His verbose, tryhard technique is a tired formula he employs without flow, direction, or meaning.

title: Weighing of the Heart
label: Ninja Tune
description: On her debut LP, British producer Nabihah Iqbal—fka Throwing Shade—has a rare touch with inky new wave synths and drum machines, emerging as a songwriter of impressive emotional heft.

title: Material Control
label: Globochem
description: On their first album in 15 years, the Long Island post-hardcore band Glassjaw picks up right where they left off. But their heaviest material yet is, at times, lacking in dynamics and atmosphere.

title: The Visitor
label: Reprise
description: While still pointedly political, Neil Young’s latest with Promise of the Real takes a more freewheeling, macro look at the world and becomes more centered than his recent albums.

title: Perfect Angel
label: Capitol
description: A deluxe reissue of Minnie Riperton’s best album—fusing funk, reggae, folk, soul—includes bonus tracks and new liner notes, which elaborate on the process of recording this classic with Stevie Wonder.

title: Everyday Is Christmas
label: RCA
description: Sia’s shiny Christmas album feels inconsistent and underwritten, like opening a gift where someone’s forgotten to remove the tags.

title: Post Self
label: Avalanche
description: The new LP from pioneering industrial band Godflesh is the duo’s best effort in over 20 years—a sinister amalgam of Justin Broadrick and G.C. Green’s collective work to date.

title: Songs of Experience
label: Island
description: Years in the making, U2’s 14th studio album finds the band straining to reassert its relevance in a world where rock music has long since ceded its vanguard status.

title: Endless Computer
label: Nuclear War Now!
description: With their vicious debut LP, Austin quartet Expander ascend to the Texas thrash pantheon, evoking familiar metal-punk sounds as well as dystopian sci-fi themes.

title: cybersex
label: Beartrap
description: With a long bench of guests from 2 Chainz to Ne-Yo, the singer’s fourth album is sometimes catchy but astonishingly hollow and derivative.

title: Metal Machine Music
label: RCA
description: Lou Reed’s 1975 album has been called one of the worst albums ever made. The truth is it is the product of genuine love and passion, still exhilarating and bursting with possibility four decades on.

title: Master of Puppets
label: Blackened Recordings
description: In 1986, Metallica released inarguably one of the best metal records of all time. Newly remastered with live takes and demos, the album’s riffs, power, and mania remain as potent as ever.

title: Oblivion
label: RCA
description: T-Pain’s first studio album in six years cashes in on the good graces he’s received in the interim, but also retreads vastly familiar territory that is more fun than illuminating.

title: Friday on Elm Street
label: Def Jam
description: On the New York rappers’ collaboration, just about every bar is sharply written, rapped, and also could’ve been plucked from any project these two have done in the 21st century.

title: Call Me By Your Name (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Madison Gate
description: The soundtrack to Italian director Luca Guadagnino’s new film uses 1980s pop singles and classical pieces to help tell the deliriously romantic story of lovers Elio and Oliver.

title: Kick
label: Atlantic
description: The 30th-anniversary edition of Kick affirms its status as a jewel of ’80s pop-rock. It’s a showcase of the band’s opulent production, slithery grooves, and the allure of Michael Hutchence’s simplicity.

title: War & Leisure
label: Bystorm
description: Miguel’s fourth album has a kinetic sexual and political energy. With less digital funk and more reverbed-out guitar, his R&B psychedelia for uncertain times shows his maturation as a songwriter.

title: Polygondwanaland
label: ATO
description: Psych-rock band King Gizzard is giving its fourth album of the year away as a free download. The immersive Polygondwanaland is the farthest the seven-piece has strayed from its psych sci-fi roots.

title: Wopavelli 3
label: 1017 Eskimos
description: Lil Wop—the newest and most adamant Gucci Mane disciple—carves his own grotty, horrorcore path on his fourth mixtape of 2017, a wildly fun but sometimes rough listen.

title: Yes Lawd! Remixes
label: Stones Throw
description: On this collection of remixes from Anderson .Paak and Knxwledge’s 2016 LP, the latter artist flexes his mastery at deconstructing beats and samples—occasionally transforming the mood of a track.

title: Colón Man
label: DDS
description: The first proper LP from Equiknoxx is a clear step forward for the Kingston-based digital dancehall duo. Its textures leap from the speakers; the sound design is more vivid than ever.

title: Rainbow Mirror
label: Hospital Productions
description: Commemorating 20 years of his Prurient alias, Dominick Fernow’s sprawling, three-hour foray into “doom electronics” feels like a swing of the pendulum back to the noise project’s Rust Belt roots.

title: Plant Age
label: L.I.E.S.
description: On his debut album, the L.I.E.S. mainstay makes house music that’s dubby and lo-fi, like club tracks heard through a pillow.

title: The Greatest Gift
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Though too scattered to stand alone, the various demos and remixes culled from Carrie & Lowell add new context and dimension to Sufjan Stevens’ masterful album.

title: Blue Lips
label: Island
description: Of a piece with last year’s Lady Wood, the Swedish pop singer’s new album chronicles the death of a doomed, passionate love affair. It makes a powerful statement about female sexuality in the process.

label: Terrible
description: Sam Gendel’s smoothly psychedelic debut is dominated by the guitarist and saxophonist’s tip-toed melodies and hushed voice.

title: Who Built the Moon?
label: Sour Mash
description: Noel Gallagher’s latest is the most ambitious of his solo releases, internalizing the heyday of late ’90s Britpop while sounding both urgent and absurd to mostly great effect.

title: Mount Qaf (Divine Love)
label: Fortune Tellers
description: Peter Matthew Bauer, bassist and organist in the Walkmen, fuses Eastern spirituality with the sound of heartland rock on his latest solo album.

title: No Dope on Sundays
label: Sony
description: After serving as one of the key writers in G.O.O.D. Music, CyHi’s thoroughly slick debut album finally arrives, with features from Kanye, Pusha T, Schoolboy Q, Travis Scott, and many more.

title: All Belief Is Paradise
label: Father/Daughter
description: The debut from pop-punk band Fits is full of sharp turns, heavy lyrics, and bursts of righteous anger. A fierce will to survive animates these lean, scrappy songs.

title: Utopia
label: One Little Indian
description: Filled with flute and birdsong, Björk’s 10th album is deeply personal, a discovery of googly-eyed romance, a rebuke of violent men, and a generous offering of love song after love song.

title: Memory of a Cut Off Head
label: Castle Face
description: The 20th LP from OCS—better known as Thee Oh Sees—is a softer and slower strand of psychedelia than the San Francisco garage-rock institution has come to be known for.
